item.name: 1001 Karawane
item.comment: A bluffing memory game that is not a total waste.

item.name: 1830: Railways & Robber Barons
item.comment: Hmmm, so this is what a heavier Chicago express/Steam feels like. It's an ok game if you are clear on the rules. The graphic design should depict many rules on the cards/board especially in the new edition. Epic economic game. Try it!

item.name: 1960: The Making of the President
item.comment: Love the theme. This game is like twilight struggle. Actual historical event cards tie in very good with the theme. My complaint from these two games, is that all these events are used to interact with some number on a territory on the map. I wish for a wider scope. Still a very nice game, and actually I think it is the best political game I've played.

item.name: 1989: Dawn of Freedom
item.comment: More streamlined than Twilight Struggle, more user-friendly for new gamers. I cannot compare them in depth since I have not played extensively neither, but I would easily prefer a game of 1989 over TS. It has certain flavors that point to specific strategies, and although it does have more mechanics, it seems easier to strategize than TS, especially for beginners.

item.name: 20th Century
item.comment: I think it's suchy's best game. Or at least the one I enjoyed most among other nice games like shipyard, league of six + expansion, last will. It has great graphics, simple system and a good economic balance. Only thing I did not very much enjoy was the tile placement which causes spatial limitations, of which I am a hater. But there are the technologies of bridges and locomotives for that.

item.name: 51st State
item.comment: With a first glance, not better than race for the galaxy.

item.name: 6 nimmt!
item.comment: Couldn't grasp the depth on my first play. It feels odd enough and may have some hidden strategies, but I am not sure about depth.

Random and continual loss of buildings throughout the game.Theme really does not incorporate into the game at all.Poor choice of colors,artwork that looks like photoshop-filtered live pictures,and mediocre abstract mechanics that don't fit in this type of game at all.

item.name: 7 Wonders
item.comment:
First opinion is that it is a fast and fulfilling light civ-themed draft game. I actually very much enjoyed it and glimpsed at some good balances but I am not able to judge fully. Want to play again!
edit: after some plays, I am still searching for some more depth.

item.name: 7 Wonders: Cities
item.comment: Unlike the leaders exp, unfortunately it does not address my main concern with 7 wonders -the lack of planning long term strategies. However it adds interesting cards. For 7w fans it's a good expansion.

item.name: 7 Wonders: Leaders
item.comment: Great expansion! it increases way up the replayability, diversity and gameplay value of the main game by introducing more ways to plan a strategy.

item.name: 7 Wonders: Manneken Pis
item.comment: Adds a tiny bit of variability but no new mechanics (except the "buy me a beer now fool" mechanic)

item.name: A la carte
item.comment: It's original and even funny when you play for the first time, but probably has zero replayability :(

item.name: Abandon Ship
item.comment: The board is fun. The mechanics, mehh, not all too bad, but it's nothing special either. I think it could have a lot more strategy.

item.name: Above and Below
item.comment: Apart that the idea of transfering a story module into a euro game is brilliant and very well implemented, the game itself is a very good euro.

item.name: Abyss
item.comment: This is a very nice game, but I do dislike the fact that it is mandatory to lose your abilities every now and then in the middle of the game.

item.name: Abyss: Kraken
item.comment: Nebuli are a good touch to the game, boosting the economic capabilities.

item.name: Ad Astra
item.comment: This is one of these games where all the mechanics are ok, but overall I felt the game doesn't have something special to offer. I can't pinpoint why I was not enthusiastic with it. Perhaps it's the fact that you are too dependent on the hidden actions of the other players, which is too random. Or that I expected it to be a bit more heavy. PS great graphic design.

item.name: Adios Amigos
item.comment: Way too simple. Main idea is ok... but... way too simple. edit: fun when you're completely wasted.

item.name: Advanced Civilization
item.comment: The added diversity in the trading resources is much appreciated!

item.name: The Adventurers: The Temple of Chac
item.comment: Nice atmospheric frontend that has the distant feel of an interactive story,but too short and simple,and considering its price I have to rate it low.Try Journey to the center of the earth.It's better.

item.name: Aeroplanes: Aviation Ascendant
item.comment: A simulation of the aviation industry, much like automobile is a simulation of the auto industry in almost the same era. The game has some very nice balances that work well, however it has a spatial element that is very fussy when trying to pick which passenger suits you. I would rather the passengers had a quantitative difficulty of obtaining, and your chances of getting them would increase with each airport. That way less luck would be involved and the players wouldn't have to worry about having an airstrip in the exact correct location.

item.name: After the Flood
item.comment: Another excellent, idiomatic, classic Wallace area control game. Love the theme and the graphics on the board. Simple mechanics, great result if you like Wallace.

item.name: Age of Empires III: The Age of Discovery
item.comment: Eurogamers and ameritrashers alike,unite!Different ways to victory.Different buildings.Specialized workers.Gather resources.Area control.Exploration.And just a small bit of battle.Perfect.For a 10,I wish it lasted 2 more rounds,and I'm not a fan of the kingmaking massacre towards the last round either.

item.name: Age of Mythology: The Boardgame
item.comment: It is a lot better than you would think.It has a lot of replayability.Perfect amount of competition,such as it attracts the non-wargamers also.Every different creature has its own unique abilities in combat.Variety of buildings,variety of action cards for each race.Very diverse!Way to go.To rate it a 10,I'd like more buildings and exploration to yield treasures or such,apart from fields .

item.name: Age of War
item.comment: This is a simplified copy of elder sign, and close to the end of the game it has major flaws.

item.name: Agricola
item.comment: Great game,delicious mechanisms,different paths to victory,magnificient artwork,wish it lasted just a bit longer,wish it was a tad easier,and a bit more unbalanced.Lots of guys say that they get a feeling that something is missing,I can remotely relate to that,but does not bother me.It is a great design.Definetely ahead of its rival (Puerto Rico) in my ranking.Uwe,thank you for the 500 different cards and combos.

item.name: Agricola CZ-Deck
item.comment: Not bad. Not essential either.

item.name: Agricola L-Deck
item.comment: There could be better mechanics than these.

item.name: Agricola: Farmers of the Moor
item.comment: The free action is a very nice addition.More choices,and lots of new cards.Great. Base game is rated a 10 with this expansion (from 9.8)

item.name: Agricola: Ã–-Deck
item.comment: Not bad. Not essential either.

item.name: Agricola: The Goodies Expansion
item.comment: Rating is only for the components. The mini expansions are really nonessential, especially the L deck which is awful.

item.name: Agricola: Through the Seasons
item.comment: A nice addition! makes the game easier and more playable, although it does require a bit of more bookkeeping.

item.name: Alcatraz: The Scapegoat
item.comment: I very much liked the win conditions, however the main mechanic of pickup and deliver was simplistic and not very challenging.

item.name: Alchemist
item.comment: This is not a game.This is just a mechanism that should be incorporated in a larger game.

item.name: Alchemists
item.comment: Best deduction game out there! congrats to mr. Kotry for the brilliant alchemical combination-deduction system. As a worker placement game resembles dungeon lords a little bit. All game elements coordinate well with each other. It is a tremendous first design. Would like to see the scoring system reflect the players' deduction skills better.

item.name: Alhambra
item.comment: I never got tile games' strategy.

item.name: Alibi
item.comment: A sleuth-like basic deduction game.

item.name: Alien Frontiers
item.comment: A Troyes with a space theme. One of the few games that have better illustrations in the main game than the cover. My problem here is the same as Troyes: I don't like plain stealing things from the opponent. I like interaction but not in such an immediate way. Oh,I rolled that, so I just steal the things you gathered. Another thing I don't like are the names on the technology cards. Too mainstream, too boring, lacks in atmosphere on that part. But overall, it's a nice Troyes alternative that has very balanced scoring.

item.name: Alles Kanone!
item.comment: A nice memory game.7 is a good number of things to remember for the human mind.

item.name: Amerigo
item.comment: Another great Feld game. It probably is the only tile placement game that the spatial element doesn't bother me. Waiting for more plays to judge depth.

item.name: Among the Stars
item.comment: The main mechanic of 7 wonders is enriched with the spatial element, and its resources are compressed into 2 main categories, money and 'rare' energy. The starting player powers are of the best I've seen in a game. This game's success depends on the individual cards' mechanics. They are already in a good path, I am waiting in anticipation to see Vaggelis' enhancements until the game is published.

item.name: Amun-Re
item.comment: Probably the best Knizia game. Refined gameplay, love the bidding mechanism, elegant rules. Love the cost increments. I'd like a more predictable way to set the Temple value though, instead of blind bidding. The choices are fluent and the game is a pretty strong, non blabbering, bidding-driven development. Excellent game. For its time it was a perfect 10 of course.

item.name: Amyitis
item.comment: A very nice euro with some development. The components and particularly the colours could be better, like assyria's. The game is ok, but could be deeper. In particular, I was not satisfied with the way resources work.

item.name: Anasazi
item.comment: Considering that its price is usually under 8 eur,I have to rate it as a fun party game that is better to play when you're completely wasted.

item.name: The Ancient World
item.comment: A very nice worker placement with some fresh mechanics. Wouldn't call it a civ though.

item.name: ...and then, we held hands.
item.comment: To begin with, excellent presentation of the theme and the different emotions by Marie Cardouat. Secondly, the game conveys succesfully the feel of cooperation and bonding between the players through its actual mechanics. A player should always keep in mind his/her partner's needs, he uses his/her deck, so in terms of incorporating theme mechanics-wise we are at excellent level.

item.name: Android
item.comment:
Almost a perfect game. I rated 8.6 due to a bit of unnecessary complexity.
The atmosphere is brilliant. The stories are good, I'd like some more or different mechanics to convert favors into vps, and the thematic concept of a "favor" does not appeal well to me. I like the "arkham horror"-style board with the buildings of various uses and the personal character stories are a great addition to the game. The conspiracy puzzle provides some extra scoring conditions so it is also a useful element, although I disagree that you should be awarded vps for completing a line.
This games confuses me. I would like to rate it a 9. On the other hand it is probably the most confusing rules-wise game I've played. Some mechanics could be refined to offer the same gameplay with less complexity. And this comes from a person that LIKES complex games. Don't get me wrong: I like the fact that lots of things are going on in the game and I wouldn't like to see them reduced. However, in this level of complexity a game requires PERFECT mechanics. I rate the mechanics a 9/10 so overall the rating of this game drops from 9 to 8.6

item.name: Android: Netrunner
item.comment: A very thematic LCG. I did have the feeling that I am a hacker, and there is a robust game. However I was not so excited with the development options as I was in Warhammer Invasion. Waiting for more plays.

item.name: Angkor
item.comment: A tile placing abstract with interaction, for fans of the genre. Not for me.

item.name: Animalia
item.comment: Why not? I liked it. And the artwork is magnificient!

item.name: another damn Civilization game
item.comment: A nice civ game indeed. I don't like the war mechanic. However it introduces nice balances and choices with some of its mechanics, particularly the dice management is great. I wish uncle Martin had made this a full game! I enjoyed it!

item.name: Antike
item.comment: An excellent minimalistic light civ with several balanced paths to victory and elegant mechanics. Similar to other Gerdts games (e.g. Rondel), yet unique. I'd wish for the very well designed vp cards to offer an extra characteristic as well, so the player could draft an ability while getting a vp. Then I'd rate close to 10. Still an excellent 2h game that plays fast and easy with many balanced choices.

item.name: Antike Duellum
item.comment: As good as Antike, which is good enough. Perhaps slightly better, through the use of event cards.

item.name: Antiquity
item.comment: This is a reference civ game. The beginning of a session is exquisite, it resembles farly "roads and boats". Many different paths to victory and buildings to build. However the late game is problematic. It gets repetitive, gathering resources all the time. A reference civ game overall.

item.name: AquÃ¤dukt
item.comment: An almost abstract family game that I actually enjoyed! it's fun to roll the dice when there are canals available! although with more effects on the board it could be even better!

item.name: AquaSphere
item.comment: Once again I bow to the Feld balance, but even for a seasoned Feld player, this game is hard to grasp on the first play. It is an action management - occasion optimizer with little drive for long term strategies, which normally I do not like but I usually make an exception for mr. Feld. I rated it lower than other Feld games because it left me with a sense of overburdening.

item.name: Archaeology: The Card Game
item.comment: A fast, easy set collection game. It's nice, but at this complexity/duration I'd recommend Biblios.

item.name: Archipelago
item.comment:
Hmm. I expected more from the game. I will give it another chance but I was not impressed. One concern is that one can not imagine that this game is an economic game with unemployment as its theme. Another concern is that a player knows only partially the endgame scoring coditions, so it is totally random who will get the vps at the end of the game.
I played as the traitor, and I can see some good mechanics there.
Another problem imo is the existence of two different markets: I didn't see a need mechanics-wise for two markets instead of one, it is confusing.
Overall unfortunately I personally did not like the game much, although I have to say that is very subjective. Some of my co-players enjoyed it.

item.name: Archon: Glory & Machination
item.comment: A nice and innovative worker placement game. It is a solid game.

item.name: Are You the Traitor?
item.comment: A nice and extra fast hidden role game, with no strategy, just acting. It is not bad!

item.name: Arkadia
item.comment: Considering its rank, I have to think that I, personally didn't like it. If it was a '90s game Î™'d give it a better rating, but for 2006 I expected more , mechanics-wise. It's too simple without having something different to offer, and it's not more fun than others of its kind.

item.name: Arkham Horror
item.comment: One of the best and more thematic Ameritrash games out there. Full of components and theme, and excellent in strategy.

item.name: Around the World in 80 Days
item.comment: Nice family game. Beautiful board.

item.name: Artifacts, Inc.
item.comment: A nice card-dice-economic game. I do not agree that it compares with "To court the king", since there aren't many cards that modify the dice, and this game has a strong economic element.

item.name: Asara
item.comment: A textbook worker placement euro game, with the theme of Palazzo. Not that bad though! there are some interesting strategies and balances and the magnificient artwork, make this a perfectly good family game that I would play again once or twice.

item.name: Ascending Empires
item.comment: Well. The strategy mechanics work well. They provide a fast and easy interactive game. The actual flicking though, does not work well. Particularly the small wooden ships flip on their side too often, rolling on the side with unpredictable trajectories. And the map sometimes obstructs movement on the interlocking sides. Overall it is balanced, a fast brawl in space with some minor development. If you're looking for fast interaction, that's it. I would recommend that the wooden ships should be plexiglass components or at least have more weight so they could be handled easily.

item.name: Ascension: Chronicle of the Godslayer â€“ Vortex Promo
item.comment: A bad one imo, with a dexterity mehanic.

item.name: Ascension: Darkness Unleashed
item.comment: An excellent expansion that adds the "level up" mechanic, which was the only thing missing from the game to be able to call it perfect.

item.name: Ascension: Deckbuilding Game
item.comment: I agree with JamesH that this is my favorite deckbuilding clone. Fast, push your luck, constant effects, great balances, deck building enjoyment. I would also like a longer variant of the game.

item.name: Ascension: Realms Unraveled
item.comment: More transform cards, and multi-unite. Not bad.

item.name: Ascension: Return of the Fallen
item.comment: A nice addition to the base game that offers more choices!

item.name: Ascension: Storm of Souls
item.comment: Great - some added mechanics but I do prefer the original.

item.name: Ascension: Storm of Souls â€“ Soul Collector Promo
item.comment: That's probably one of the best promos there are, considering all games.

item.name: Ascension: Theme Pack â€“ Rat King
item.comment: Nice mechanic!

item.name: Assault on Doomrock
item.comment: Lots of fresh mechanics in this adventure game. I particularly liked the pre-battle phase and the different opportunities in the territory cards, and the tactics aspect of the game is introduced elegantly through the token engagement mechanic. Other than that, I would wish that the battles are shorter, less massive and more in number, like in other adventure games.

item.name: Assyria
item.comment: An excellent semi-development game,semi-eurogame(maybe a bit civ-like,as tempus for example),balanced that offers some different strategies to discover.When I have more plays the rating might go higher.

item.name: At the Gates of Loyang
item.comment: It can't be compared with Agricola or Le havre.A bit frustrating,weird and not as much fun as one would expect.

item.name: Atlanteon
item.comment: Mainstream abstract strategy.Not so bad.

item.name: Atlantis
item.comment: Meh.It's a racing game with some strategies, rush vs gather vps.Not useless but wouldn't recommend it either.

item.name: AtmosFear: Khufu â€“ The Mummy
item.comment: A simple party game supported by a funny dvd that produces laughs for the first few times.

item.name: Aton
item.comment: A reference abstract area control game. Fast and robust gameplay with depth and different ways to win. A very nice duel.

item.name: Attika
item.comment: Exceptional graphic design and an interesting game.Wish it was more complex.Wish it was a civ game actually,but...

item.name: Attribute
item.comment: Nice idea, needed more robust mechanics to allow discussions, capture the fun and perhaps add a bit more strategy.

item.name: Augustus
item.comment: Any game that makes the "bingo" mechanic work, deserves my respect. I would enjoy the game even more if it had a later end condition, and if all goals were easier (in order for someone to be able to perform more combos). It is also untolerable that most of the resources aren't used in the base game.

item.name: Automobile
item.comment: Another example of Martin Wallace's excellence in creating complexity with simple rules. This game also simulates very elegantly a competitive industry. Another good one from uncle Martin.

item.name: Aye, Dark Overlord!
item.comment: A nice party game with just perfect artwork that is as good as the humour of the people who play it.One could explore the possibility the cards providing more directions in the way that people use them to make up their stories.

item.name: Backgammon
item.comment: This is a deep abstract game,extremely popular in Greece,tought mainly by the elderly to young children.I started liking it after 50 plays and before I got into boardgames I played at least twice a day.

item.name: Bakong
item.comment: A simple racing game with some abilities. Nothing too fancy. I do not think it deserves such a low rank though.

item.name: Bamboleo
item.comment: A fun balancing dexterity game. I'd like to see some variants on the initial setup.

item.name: BANG!
item.comment: An almost replayable party/secret role game for me.Expansions might make it a lot better.I have to try them.

item.name: Barbarian Prince
item.comment: A great solo adventure game. Outstanding for its time. Binds "tales of the arabian nights" with adventure games. Would like to have more plays to judge. I found the lack of obvious options to increase your stats a bit frustrating, but I enjoyed the experience!

item.name: Basilica
item.comment: Played a game, not a fan of area influence games. Did not enjoy it I am afraid, although I can see many nice design decisions. Perhaps if the tile placement was even more limited and specific, it would be an even better game. Area control fans may like it.

item.name: Batavia
item.comment: Well.. the idea is ok. Stock holding and manipulation of how long you can hold on to each company. The game rewards the typical strategies, the board is beautiful, BUT: not so much fun or strategic gameplay. I don't know what was wrong. Perhaps it needed maturity on the main path-advance mechanic. Overall, a medium value game that could however be loved by newcomers to the hobby.

item.name: Battle Cattle: The Card Game
item.comment: A simpler, uglier and more pointless mag blast.

item.name: The Battle for Hill 218
item.comment: A compact and cheap tactics game,deep strategies,but I wished for more complex cards & effects.

item.name: Battle Line
item.comment: It seems to have some depth but I failed to grasp any substantial depth from the first play. Perhaps it's because I played in a crowded area. Waiting for second play to judge better. Simple numbers game, which leaves room for extra strategy.

item.name: Battleground: Crossbows & Catapults War Chest Starter Set
item.comment: Nice dexterity/thematic game! I use reinforced rubber bands! the rules are simplistic but the fun is there.

item.name: Battles of Westeros
item.comment: I do not yet have played battlelore to compare, but it seemed like a perfect and simple battle thing that flows nicely.

item.name: Battlestar Galactica
item.comment: A very nice and balanced space simulation that provides room for a lot of maneuvering and hidden agendas.Excellent theme incorporation.I don't like-actually hate-the theme and the live photos.It would be a 10 with a different theme.

item.name: Battlestar Galactica: Exodus Expansion
item.comment: An ok expansion if you like a twist in the main game. I particularly liked the new loyalty cards that give you an extra goal to care about, however I do not find this expansion essential.

item.name: Battlestar Galactica: Pegasus Expansion
item.comment: Some very nice additions included in this expansion.

item.name: Bausack
item.comment: One of the good dexterity games out there,and it provides room for just a bit of strategy as well.Though I think a designer could do something even better.The pieces are masterfully designed, but I needed more tricky rules.

item.name: Bayon
item.comment: A very simple set collection game, but very repetitive and without anything new to show.

item.name: Before the Wind
item.comment: A basic 3-stages resource movement game, from your hand to the warehouse, and then load to the ships to score vps. Like colonia but simpler and almost as good. The artwork is filtered photos I think.

item.name: Belfort
item.comment: A good worker placement game but does not approach excellence and is not too innovative.

item.name: Beowulf: The Movie Board Game
item.comment: It's ok if you're into algebraic tile placement, but it has nothing to do with the theme.

item.name: Betrayal at House on the Hill
item.comment: Not very compact strategically,but if it was,it would be the best game I've played.With 50 different scenarios and text that flirts with lovecraft,it sure is a play-at-least-once-in-a-lifetime.The most atmospheric game I have ever played.

item.name: Biblios
item.comment: Fast and fun push your luck/bidding/set collection game. It's nice although it misses some variance.

item.name: Big Manitou
item.comment: A superlight trick taking-like game. Not bad. Not something special either. If you don't have anything else to play, it is not a complete waste of time. Players assign tribe members in 3 tile areas and then compare strengths to see who will claim the right to gather a tile first. It would be a lot better if there were lots of different tile effects, but there are only 4 different effects.

item.name: Bitch Slap
item.comment: A potent and innovative dexterity game.

item.name: Black Sheep
item.comment: Looks good, feels good, but is not good. I don't know. The main idea seemed to work well when reading the manual, but the actual gameplay is a bit dull and not as strategic as one would expect.

item.name: Black Stories
item.comment: Although this is not a boardgame,and it can be played with no components at all,I have to say that some of the stories are brilliant.Some not so.

item.name: Blackbeard
item.comment: A reference pirate simulation game. The newer merchants and marauders borrowed much from the main gameplay structure. The manual is written as in all simulation games. Very difficult to hold in all the info on the first pass, and there isn't any easier walkthrough. However the game itself is not that complex at all. I could call it a serious family game that lasts very long. It is a good pirate game that has lots of stuff to do, but misses something overly exciting mechanics-wise. I enjoyed the game. Would I prefer merchants and marauders? well if you're not a dedicated simulation fan, maybe. My choice is to wait around for an even more complex pirate game.

item.name: Blokus 3D
item.comment: An typical abstract game that is more an IQ test than a game. It's a bit fun if you don't sit and think about it, but I would not play many times.

item.name: Blood Bowl: Team Manager â€“ The Card Game
item.comment: A nice interactive deck building game. Very much enjoyed the fact that even the lost party gains something (makes the game a bit like worker placement). The mechanics didn't thrill me but it's a pretty ok game.

item.name: Blue Moon City
item.comment: Magnificient artwork! bravo. As for the gameplay, this is a really promising game that lacks something I cannot pinpoint. Perhaps some more development on mr Knizia's part or a bit of house rules would make it better.

item.name: Bluff
item.comment: Not as boring as it seems. Fun! Very replayable for a superlight game.

item.name: Bobby Sitter
item.comment: still laughing! :D excellent!! and evil!

item.name: La Boca
item.comment: A puzzle semi coop game that seems to work well and contain nice design ideas. If the main mechanic had some variability, it wouldn't get so boring in the middle of the first play.

item.name: Bohnanza
item.comment: Too simple for my taste and I don't very much like the trade feature. "Parked" at a friend's house.

item.name: Bombay
item.comment: Not a bad eurogame. Action management. Competitive. Nothing too special though.

item.name: Boomtown
item.comment: For its price,it's quite ok.I wish it had better money components instead of the poker chips though

item.name: Bora Bora
item.comment: At last, after so many years, alea shows mercy to Feld fans and displays a great production value! Bora bora has exactly the theme of Hawaii, another great euro released almost the same time. Regarding complexity it is between burgen von burgund and trajan. Regarding the gameplay, it is a great euro game. There is the endeavor-style mechanic, in the aspect that you control which type of actions will be available for you each round. There is also the burgen von burgund element in which you get rewards for completing a set of pre-determined goals. (there are also random goals in the game) The game is very good, and I put it among Feld's finest games. However, I particularly dislike the fact that only the last builder in each teriitory scores the points. I aim for a variant that reduces this chaos. My rating if we disregard this rule is 9.4

item.name: Bora Bora: Orange God Tiles
item.comment: Nothing too fancy, counters a bit of ill luck that players may have regarding their dice.

item.name: The Boss
item.comment: A nice light deduction - risk taking bidding game with bluff.

item.name: Boss Monster: The Dungeon Building Card Game
item.comment: Delicious graphics, the mechanics do work but they could also be better to provide more depth. I found them a bit simplistic. A central aid to keep track of your opponents' current bid state wouldn't hurt, since it can become difficult to constantly keep checking other people's boards for changes.

item.name: Braggart
item.comment: Needs home rules to boost storytelling / party game aspect.

item.name: Brass
item.comment:
One needs some plays to fully grasp and appreciate this game.It seems that players co-depend on each other but also compete.It also seems that resources are scarce but you must also plan ahead in surely spending all of them.Weird mechanisms,classic Wallace.The graphic design could be better,to depict the rules on the tiles and on the board.
after some plays: An excellent overall game with strategies that you will discover for some time and sweetspot balances. Replayability top.

item.name: Brawling Barons
item.comment: A pretty nice light filler. Would be great if it had triple the abilities, but it's quite good as it is. If it had the gameplay weight of glory to rome (if it were heavier), I'd buy it.

item.name: Bridge Troll
item.comment: A great euro with a fun theme and well balanced mechanics.I wanted more complex villagers,with more special effects each.Still a very good game for its simplicity.This game's rank should not be 1800!!

item.name: Briefcase
item.comment:
Fast, fun, good gameplay with good use of a very simple deck building mechanism, a game with various tough development choices. One of the good light economic - resource management games out there and with great artwork!
Very good work by sakal, sot07 and artipia games!

item.name: Bruges
item.comment: Another nice Feld game. There is some synergy between cards and there is the balanced choice between gaining VP's the standard way and via the card synergy. A good euro overall.

item.name: Buccaneer
item.comment: I can't believe Stefan Dorra made this game. Almost pointless.

item.name: The Bugman's Game
item.comment: Pointless back and forth. Great artwork, funny theme but non-existent gameplay.

item.name: Bunny Bunny Moose Moose
item.comment: It's a very nice idea for a party game but I'm not sure it works so well when applied. The game works ok for a few times but I don't see any replayability. Gets pretty tiring after a while. However it seems great as a kids game.

item.name: Byzantio
item.comment: Innovative mechanic meets area control. This is a fast, simple and light game, with conflict and hidden goals. A number of pre-selected actions are at each player's disposal and he is called to choose the best moment to use them. Other players do not know each other's goal, so suspense builds up during the session. I'd like it even heavier though.

item.name: Byzantium
item.comment: Another classic Wallace game. Distilled strategy of a light wargame but an excellent economic game. Lots of interesting details in this diamond, like the "Hannibal" retreat rules, the fact that you forfeit your faction vps if they are less than half of the other faction vp's etc (brilliant mechanic!). Excellent game overall, without being too complex like other Wallace games. I loved too many different small details to list here.

item.name: Byzanz
item.comment: Fast and plays with 6. Nice artwork and plastic cards. What else can one expect from a small light bidding game.

item.name: Ca$h 'n Gun$
item.comment: A fun party game. You get to point your "gun" at your friends. What more could you ask? and it doesn't even require reading the manual! I would like a bit more suspense in the 5 banknotes, probably increased banknotes range (e.g. 5-50) in order to provide handlers for more predictable behaviour. Would like to try the expansion as well.

item.name: Cadwallon: City of Thieves
item.comment: By looking at the production one imagines a brilliant game. However it is a boring, very simplistic game. There are various promising elements, e.g. the exceptional artwork, the different scenarios, the different treasures and the 2-5-8 vp set collection distribution, the different character abilities, the arcana cards e.t.c. however 2 main gameplay issues ruin the game: 1)the city is claustrophobic and conflict is inevitable, in a way that it makes any strategy pointless. Everywhere it's almost the same thing: hit the guy who tries to get to the treasure and send him 3 blocks back. :( 2)what do I do in my round? I simply move 4 spaces, and then roll a die to see if I pushed the other guy or if I got the treasure. Maybe I'm wrong and the game is better. However I don't think even a 14-y.o. would enjoy it.

item.name: Caesar & Cleopatra
item.comment: One of the best 2 player games at that price.

item.name: Call of Cthulhu: Collectible Card Game
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game
item.comment: I need some more plays to judge. Love the theme, but I am not extremely thrilled about the gameplay in comparison to other lcg-ccg's.

item.name: Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game â€“ Ancient Horrors Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game â€“ The Antediluvian Dreams Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game â€“ The Horror Beneath the Surface Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game â€“ The Mountains of Madness Asylum Pack
Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game â€“ The Spawn of the Sleeper Asylum pack
Campanile
item.comment: I got the impression that any strategy up to the last few rounds is futile.Great card quality.Mediocre artwork.Some strategy.

item.name: Can't Stop
item.comment: Fun with dice!great design.Rating may go up.

item.name: El CapitÃ¡n
item.comment: For such an abstract game it's not that bad. I'd like some more mechanics of course, but still. I can play it again a few times.

item.name: Carcassonne
item.comment: Never got the strategy of tile games.You can't remember what the tiles are,so you do the best you can with the random tile you get.No strategy in that.You can't plan ahead.

item.name: Carcassonne: Abbey & Mayor
item.comment: Probably the best expansion, almost essential.

item.name: Carcassonne: Expansion 1 â€“ Inns & Cathedrals
item.comment: A pretty nice addition to the base game.

item.name: Carcassonne: Expansion 2 â€“ Traders & Builders
item.comment: Another good expansion for the base game. Particularly the builder is essential!

item.name: Carcassonne: The River
item.comment: Not bad at all. A nice flavour to the basic game.

item.name: Carcassonne: Wheel of Fortune
item.comment: Don't buy vanilla Carcassonne.This is a MUST version if you like Carcassonne.I disagree with most people that say it adds luck to the game.I say it adds more options,therefore more strategy,especially with the possibility of returning one meeple of your choice from the board.

item.name: Cards Against Humanity
item.comment: This is a card game version of say anything, with greater questions. Could use some variants to become even more interesting.

item.name: Career Poker
item.comment: A dalmutti clone.

item.name: Cargo Noir
item.comment: A very nice looking and fluent light bidding game. The balances work, so the game is good.

item.name: Carpe Astra
item.comment: Opportunistic, abstract, excellently illustrated. Too opportunistic though. There are no long term strategies available-I think.

item.name: Carson City
item.comment:
I'd prefer that it lasted +50% , that it had a bit exploration in it, and that after you had lost a duel you could place your pawn somewhere else instantly, particularly in the last round of the game. I would also like to see the attacker/dueler having to pay something in order to place his pawn in a taken spot. If these things existed it would be almost perfect.
Putting those aside, it's a very good game overall! I like the different actions and its balance. I like the building interactions and the worker placement.

item.name: Carson City: The Indian
item.comment: Useful.

item.name: Cartagena
item.comment: This is a simple game with lots of different hidden strategies,which I guess is the goal in designing such games,however I needed more effects and player's choices available to call it buyable.

item.name: Cash-a-Catch
item.comment: A nice and balanced auction game with a dexterity twist,in the simplicity of For Sale.An obvious disadvantage is that it doesn't play with 6.

item.name: Castaways
item.comment: Thematically and mechanics wise at many points, it's the same as robinson crusoe, with minor strategic differences. A good game overall but there is no point in owning both games. I do not like the plastic components.

item.name: A Castle for All Seasons
item.comment: One of Menzel's magnificient boards in a role selection/worker placement game. Delicious mechanism affecting your scoring conditions by placing workers, however the main resource gaining gameplay required a bit more imagination. Still a perfectly good game!

item.name: The Castle of the Devil
item.comment: Secret roles? special abilities? different items? plays with 10? simple to teach to nongamers? one of the best party games.

item.name: Castle Panic
item.comment: Way too simple for my taste.Coop play is solitaire with supernumeraries

item.name: The Castles of Burgundy
item.comment: This is probably the most characteristic Feld game. It seems like a "review", a "summary" of some of his recent games. There are combos and hidden strategies to master and it seems to have sustained a great deal of playtesting. It is a perfectly good euro game, however I prefer his other 3 diamonds, In the year, Notre Dame, and Macao.

item.name: The Castles of Burgundy: 1st Expansion â€“ New Player Boards
The Castles of Burgundy: 2nd Expansion â€“ New Hex Tiles
item.comment: Pretty nice expansion, nothing too fancy. Boosts scoring a bit.

item.name: Castles of Mad King Ludwig
item.comment: Suburbia the light-family-fast version. A good game, I love the hilarious tile shapes and the end result (mad castle indeed), although the game felt it ended abruptly.

item.name: Cat & Chocolate
item.comment: A simplistic storytelling game that can provide lots of laughs.

item.name: Catan
item.comment: Best introductory game ever,and a great game with the Cities&knights expansion

item.name: Catan Card Game
item.comment: One of the best 2p games out there.Although it is not Catan.Same feel,different strategy.

item.name: Catan Dice Game
item.comment: I would like a more elaborate dice rolling mechanic, but still it's an ok solitaire game.

item.name: Catan: Cities & Knights
item.comment: I find it very disturbing that they sell Catan without this expansion.It should be included by standard in every catan game from now on.It takes the game to another level.

item.name: Cave Troll
item.comment: It's an ok game, but I think it's been "fired" by Dungeon Twister. Although for a light area control with a fantasy theme it works ok.

item.name: Caverna: The Cave Farmers
item.comment:
Agricola v. 2.0 - but is it better than Agricola? It seems comparable. It does address some issues on agricola that bothered me, but I cannot judge the gameplay depth yet. Professions and minor improvements are missing and they are fixed buildings now. It is also easier to have stray animals in your farm. Deluxe component are included in the vanilla edition.
2nd play and the game seems legit.

item.name: Cavum
item.comment: The game seems professionaly designed, balanced, with very good production value, however the gameplay itself is not my style. I was bored while playing the game.

item.name: Caylus Expansion: The Jeweller
item.comment: An extra building. Why not.

item.name: Caylus Magna Carta
item.comment:
Exceptional,compact,highly strategic,nice gameplay.Could be a bit more fun-and perhaps even better-if it was a bit more unbalanced.Perhaps a unique building for each player and some more prestige buildings with properties.I even liked it more than the original Caylus!it holds all the strategy in about half the time. I love the different features, like the secondary action and the hand management element.
after some plays, I still prefer it from the original Caylus.

item.name: Caylus Magna Carta: The Favors
item.comment: Enhances the base game greatly, making it almost preferable to original Caylus.

item.name: Caylus Premium Limited Edition
item.comment: The master of replayability.Innovative for its time and still a classic due to its depth.The card game version is great as well.Buy the deluxe edition if you can find it.The art is way better.

item.name: Chang Cheng
item.comment: 20 years ago it would be a masterpiece of a game.But in 2007 I expected something more than "whoever places the most walls in each section gets the vps of the section".Too simple a mechanism.

item.name: Chaos in the Old World
item.comment: Very well balanced variable player powers,but the coloring of the board is missing something.And some art on the cards would be nice too.A more mainstream pitch to the card effects would be nice.Great miniatures.I think a 2nd ed. with new card effects/components is going to make this game keep its place on the top 50.

item.name: Cheaty Mages!
item.comment: It can produce some laughs, but it does not pass as a pure party game, rather as a light strategy game - and at that category I can't say I was satisfied.

item.name: Cherokee
item.comment: I did like the pyramid mechanic but the game seemed way too fiddly, which takes out the fun for me, thus the low rating. Excellent component quality though. Not fond of the artwork.

item.name: Chess
item.comment: It may be old and deep, but for me it is not fun. It needs many plays before the real strategy kicks in. Before that,it's just who can think more moves ahead-which is not strategy,it's an IQ test. I'd rather play In the year of the dragon, it's also open info and way better.

item.name: Chez Geek
item.comment: Like Munchkin, brilliant fluff (rated 10) but the actual strategic choices diminish after the 1st play.

item.name: Chicago Express
item.comment: A very good market prospecting-bidding game with a beautiful Menzel hex board.I would like the building action to perform something more interesting and the trains to pick more bonuses along the way,a set collection mechanism also perhaps to call it perfect.

item.name: China
item.comment: Although I do not like area control games, the mature and balanced mechanics in this game make me respect it. It's also fast and offers easy flow of play. But after all it's an area control game so I won't rate very high.

item.name: Chinatown
item.comment: A fine negotiating euro. Nothing too special but it is not disappointing either.

item.name: Chocolatl
item.comment: A beautiful bidding euro. Nothing innovative, but nothing bad either. Works well and it is a strategic family game. Its rank should be a lot higher! it is an injustice for this game to be at rank 2500. I would put it around 700.

item.name: Chronicle
item.comment: Love letter + trick taking + variable goals in each round = promising game but too much to process for such a small game. If you like trick taking with abilities, this is for you!

item.name: Chronology
item.comment: Timeline is similar to this game. Pretty fun and fast. One of the trivia games of choice!

item.name: Citadels
item.comment: Respect!I am a fan. one of the best games for large groups.

item.name: Citadels: The Dark City
item.comment: This is en essential expansion that I love dearly.It takes citadels a huge leap further.A MUST if you have rated citadels 5 or higher! despite my many plays I have a shrinkwrapped copy for trade.

item.name: La CittÃ
item.comment: One of the few area control games I can stand.Wish there were more types of buildings with different abilities each.Wish it lasted a bit longer.There could be buildings that let you demolish your own buildings,that let you choose among more cards,e.t.c.Why not?come on you guys,you had a real good basis here for a perfect 10 game.

item.name: CiÃºb
item.comment: Unfortunately it is the only Lehmann game I've played that I didn't enjoy. I dislike the fact that there is no development since you are obligated to return to 5 dice after purchasing a spell. Other people have enjoyed the game.

item.name: Civilization
item.comment: An excellent balanced civ game, that amazes me. The mechanics were way ahead of its time and most of the contemporary civ games have copied them, like roll through the ages in the resources counters. The game is very enjoyable, comparable to modern civ games. I find it better than, say, sid meier's civ 2010. I would like to invent a trade variant rule to decrease gameplay time. It is a great game, very balanced, with non-brutal area control. Try it if you don't mind the archaic components.Another thing that increases game time is the constant conflict and movement, perhaps a if the attacker had to sacrifice something in order to attack the game would be less chaotic and with substantially smaller gamelength.

item.name: Clash of Cultures
item.comment: I compare it to sid meier's civ 2010, a very nice mix of civ and wargame, with a great tech tree. I rate both games equally. I will not play the game often, for the same reason that I won't play sid meier's civ often: war tactics/grid movement could play a major role in the outcome, a feature that I dislike in most civ games.

item.name: Claustrophobia
item.comment: An excellent minimalistic dungeon crawl with theme and meaningful tactics, a feat difficult for a designer to perform.

item.name: Cleopatra and the Society of Architects
item.comment: Days of wonder components save the day and illustrate beuatifully this simple family game. I would like some more mechanics to call it a complete perfect euro that passes the excellent (8.5 mark) for me. I like of course the corruption element, but apart from that, the choices of the players are not so rich as they seem. The game of course looks wonderful and it is recommended as an early family game. Not bad at all.

item.name: Cockroach Salad
item.comment: One fun superlight real time game. Like geistesblitz. Î™ prefer geistesblitz.

item.name: Coda
item.comment: Very good abstract game. Makes sense, plays fast, has deduction.

item.name: Codenames
item.comment: A succesful party game, but overhyped I fear.

item.name: Cold War: CIA vs KGB
item.comment: Fast, simple, replayable and with substantial depth. Of course I wish there were more than 4 different group abilities. One of my 2p games of choice when there is not much space/time available.

item.name: Colonia
item.comment: A pimped version of before the wind. A respectable pure euro,resource converting triple time,with nothing too exciting to offer.I can't pinpoint what's missing from the game,since strategically it looks robust. Slight changes in the mechanics should offer the boost the game is lacking.

item.name: Colonialism
item.comment: A very good area influence game with original mechanics, not too heavy.

item.name: Colosseum
item.comment: Never play this game with more than one competitive person in the party.Very nice looking board.

item.name: Combat Commander: Europe
item.comment: hmm. I didn't like it much. I wouldn't mind more rules for a more realistic feel, but these rules just didn't stick well with me. There is the restricting element of card driven wargames,and although I didn't find it disturbing in memoir 44,it bothered me here. Perhaps a hand limit of 6 cards? anyway,maybe I need another try, since everybody else seems to enjoy it much.

item.name: Commands & Colors: Ancients
item.comment: Memoir'44 system with advanced rules but lesser components.Enjoyable and fast gameplay but not my wargame of choice.

item.name: Concept
item.comment: A very nice idea that works well and produces laughs. The game does need a better scoring system but it's fun.

item.name: Conflict of Heroes: Awakening the Bear! â€“ Russia 1941-42
item.comment: Yes.I compare this game to Combat Commander and find it better.I liked the action point mechanic.I liked the facing.I liked the fact that I can fire several times my machinegun if I don't move.I liked the uncertain resolution of my hits.I liked the scoring each round.And the quality of counters is way better than other standard wargames. I consider this game my point of reference for wargames.

item.name: Constantinopolis
item.comment: A well designed development game. This is the definition of a euro game that has nothing new to offer BUT is a very good game that I could play many times. Although it does not raise the bar very high, it does offer solid gameplay with NO mistakes by its designer, so it is a good game to play, with nice production quality by FF. I can't find anything wrong with the game.
item.conditiontext: German version, language independent, components in perfect condition, box with a visible repaired tear across the front edge of the box, otherwise in great shape.

item.name: Copycat
item.comment:
A meta-themed game. Excellent theme/idea, the sarcastic plagiarism! kudos sir! I was actually waiting for a renowned designer to troll this subject :D
as for the mechanics: the game feels like "dominion the boardgame" without the different setups.
the through the ages card row copy works Perfectly. the worker placement thing also works very good! the agricola stage by stage action works ok. the dominion thing...well I'd like 2 or 3 more special actions to call it perfect.
I think they all tie in very well together, which made me enjoy the game much. Have no idea about its balance or depth, particularly I'm worried for the 1-2 last rounds. Have to play many times to judge that.
overall, I enjoyed it. waiting to see if there is strategy after the excitement.

item.name: Core Worlds
item.comment:
I feel the game starts off greatly, but then as we closed in on the end I kind of lost track or lost the feeling of control over my deck. I struggled over some vp balances, and some of the later cards seem pointless since they would not yield many times over their ability. I'd like a bit more control over my deck. Perhaps 2 decks per player wouldn't be a bad idea in this game. Overall a great deck building game.
meta-comment: I had the feeling of losing control towards the end also in another Andrew Parks game, Parthenon.

item.name: Cosmic Encounter
item.comment: A refined bluffing/negotiation game that is as good as the players who play it.

item.name: Coup
item.comment: An alternative to love letter, I like the game but it produces too often some bad "back and forth" situations.

item.name: COâ‚‚
item.comment:
A pretty nice balanced euro that seems to have sustained a lot of playtesting. I was not excited but I respect it as a game. Not bad. I'd prefer endeavor over it.
What I didn't find perfect: some actions are not interesting towards the endgame (point made by tavlas) there are no "broken" strategies, as in the room for developing/optimizing a specific strategy - game is a bit more opportunistic than I'd like - I think. the events are dull I did not feel the pollution level threatening me much. I'd like more character to the specific energy sources
what I liked: Excellent colour choice, kudos graphic designer! nice euro game. many mechanics used well. original theme

item.name: Crokinole
item.comment: From the family of expensive wooden flick dexterity games, I don't agree that it is on top. I enjoyed tumblin dice better. I was left with the feeling that the rules and the setup could be tweaked to provide even more depth and room for strategy.

item.name: Crunch: The Game for Utter Bankers
item.comment: It delivers what it promises. A satire of the banking system, humorous and thematic. Try to hide cards in your clothing without the other players noticing you while dealing with the game's pretty nice light economic simulation.

item.name: Cuba
item.comment:
A short resource management/economic game with very nice components. I wish the scale was tipped on the complexity side, more buildings, more complicated, more game time, more vp engine building. It left me with a so-so feel, like it was good but not there yet. The laws really don't convince me at all. Still, it is a good game that I'd play again.
After some plays, I think I overrated the game :( the spatial element and the constantly changing laws add unnecessary frustration to the gameplay.

item.name: Cuba Libre
item.comment: A very thematic simulation. I prefer not having to manage my hand and I very much liked the pass option and the asymmetry. 2 negative points that I did not prefer were the chaos of the situation, and the bad player aid. Another observation is that I did not feel like playing a whole new genre of game (COIN) in comparison to other GMT card driven games. It still is about choosing when to act and where to invest your powers on the map.

item.name: Cuba: El Presidente
item.comment: Unfortunately, apart from the +2 game turns and the lawyer, this does not address succesfully the issues of the main game for me. I wished for opportunities for more elaborate vp engine building, perhaps an expansion to the players' farms as well, etc. And almost all of the new roles seem unattractive.

item.name: CV
item.comment: Same theme with "funny friends", very different mechanics. I prefer this one. I call this a reference game in that it lets you build an engine and choose the point were you stop building an engine and shift to VP hunting. The only flaw I found is that it needed a better catch-up mechanic as the current one seems pasted on during playtesting.

item.name: CV: Promo Cards
item.comment: Thematic cards, but not essential mechanics-wise.

item.name: Cyclades
item.comment: An excellent,definitely eurotrash game.Mechanisms that provide balance,development,excitement,and excellent gameplay in medium simplicity!A must play for all eurotrashers!It is brilliantly balanced.Play and see for yourself.

item.name: D-Day Dice
item.comment: An excellent push your luck wargame with tough and strategic choices usually between developing your unit, sacrificing, and pushing forward.

item.name: Dancing Eggs
item.comment: GREAT!GREAT!GREAT!

item.name: Dark Tower
item.comment: A pretty nice adventure for its age! even today I enjoyed it! there is a vintage feel of course, but there is also some resource management strategy! Not a waste of time.

item.name: David & Goliath
item.comment: Another unique variation of common trick taking games. Not bad. Two apparent ways to score, catchy title.

item.name: Day & Night
item.comment: A nice abstract game. It is a very good try but I am not sure about its depth. I expect depth from abstract games, and the fact that I only have 12 hours decreases significantly the combos/surprises that happen during the game. Perhaps movement should be on a separate track and the cards could be also separated in two decks, a simple one that reverses tiles and a more intrigued one so the player could choose. Then I would boost the game's rating.

item.name: Dead of Winter: A Crossroads Game
item.comment: It is a well-tested game with a nice flow. It combines mechanics/ambience from battlestar galactica, robinson crusoe, betrayal at house on the hill etc, without being unoriginal at all. However, from the first play I did not grasp why it is considered that good to be on the top 20.

item.name: Deadwood
item.comment: Reminds me of Carson city, but is worse. I did not like the fact that I had to either place or displace one of my workers. Too unproductive. Although it has some interesting choices.

item.name: Descent: Journeys in the Dark
item.comment: Very unclear rules.Nice fantasy/tactics/adventure,but I wanted more choices on the battle mechanics.Not just choose a weapon,roll the dice and calculate the distance.

item.name: Descent: Journeys in the Dark (Second Edition)
item.comment:
Opinion in comparison to the 1st edition+road to legend: Not sure if it's way better. There are many elements that are improved, like the defense and the reinforcements-spawning system, los, monster movement etc, but I hate the fact that you don't get real treasure or level-ups while in the dungeon and you have to buy it in between adventures. This makes the game almost purely tactical in nature. I'd surely break that rule if I designed dungeons.
Opinion without comparing to the 1st edition: great dungeoncrawling game! wished for more yummy treasures.

item.name: Descent: The Well of Darkness
item.comment: I expected more.The overlord gets a lot more interesting to play,but I wanted at least 3 times more items.Road to Legend is the same price and weighs 2 times more...

item.name: Deus
item.comment: A development/resource management game with an engine that relies on expansion. Not bad at all.

item.name: Diamant
item.comment: Nice,easy,fun,push your luck party game.Its weight is on the sweet spot for a party game.

item.name: Diavolo
item.comment: Nice arithmetic dexterity - reaction game. Produces about the same feel as adios amigos.

item.name: Dice Brewing
item.comment: To begin with, this game has exquisite graphic design. The theme is very nice also and I was excited to play a brewing game with dice. However - many of the abilities offer pointless, frustrating "take that" interaction. Being able to just do destructive things to your opponent is not the good kind of interaction I am looking for in a euro game with a brewing theme. In the first round after just having heard the instructions the game seemed promising, but during the play I was a bit let down, didn't seem robust enough.

item.name: Discworld: Ankh-Morpork
item.comment: A nice family game with great artwork on the cards! it might not reach the depths of other Wallace game but it is a perfectly ok family game with some interesting mechanics, like the use of cards and the hidden goals.

item.name: Dixit
item.comment: Such a great idea and great cards,with such a poor mechanic.The storyteller can simply frown and put his card down.Chances are that he'll get at least one vote and 3 points. My Variant:Storyteller has TWO cards he must describe as a story.If all votes fall on those 2 cards,he loses.If any of the 2 cards doesn't get at least 1 vote,he loses.This way he can't just simply say a random thing.

item.name: Dixit Quest
item.comment: Still awesome artwork. Really like to meet the artist.

item.name: Dominant Species
item.comment: Clearly one of the good area control games. There are interesting mechanics and I like the cards and the duality between elements (dominance) and quantity of species (direct scoring). This duality however offers a bit too many choices. I'd like to see a connection between these two fields of conflict. I found the worker placement choices excellent. Although the elements system...I think it should shrink a bit because the choices there are a bit confusing. Never try the 2/3 player variant where each player controls 2 animals. Thematically it reminded me of evo and valley of the mammoths. A bit overpriced. Graphic design is good (I'd like an area in each tile to place the cubes that have already moved for that round), and I wouldn't mind some illustrations at that price.

item.name: Dominant Species: The Card Game
item.comment: A trick taking game with a take-that element and some interesting exceptions in its strategy. Not bad, not anything special either. I liked the dynamics of the last round, but it is very possible that you will not have the chance to play all the cards you gathered. Poor graphic design.

item.name: Dominant Species: The Card Game (Promo Card Set)
item.comment: Nice cards, not anything special or needed.

item.name: Dominare
item.comment:
Yes - the mechanics work very good. I still need a few things to call this game perfect though: a) per round scoring b) more playtested card abilities, less chaotic towards the end c) perhaps a better use of money
One of the very very few area control games I'd play again.

item.name: Dominion
item.comment: The reference deck building game, for a reason: elegant design.

item.name: Dominion: Dark Ages
item.comment: Shelters and upgrading are 2 of the most interesting features in any expansion.

item.name: Dominion: Intrigue
item.comment: New cards. Doesn't alter the game in a very different way but the card diversity it adds is good.

item.name: Dominion: Seaside
item.comment: A very interesting expansion for Dominion that changes many mainstream concepts.

item.name: Don
item.comment: A bidding game, fast, light, with some nice balances. Not bad at all!

item.name: The Downfall of Pompeii
item.comment: Very nice and simple game,I wish it was a bit more complicated though,with special effect cards etc

item.name: Dragonheart
item.comment: Beautifully illustrated by Menzed, a light card game with lots of hidden strategies and almost no explanation time. It is also very fast and has some depth not apparent at first glance. Worth a try!

item.name: Drako
item.comment: An excellent mini game. I love the feature that I have been longing to see in a boardgame, the fact that you can target specific areas of an opponent and cripple his corresponding abilities.

item.name: Dream Factory
item.comment: I disagree with this game's high rank. It seems a pretty fair bidding game, but not something special that deserves top 300.

item.name: Drum Roll
item.comment:
Comment while playtesting: An excellent basic structure for a euro of the sweetspot complexity.
For the final product: Worthy economic euro with balanced development choices.
I could do with some more personnel (which I found in the mini expansions) and even more character(mechanics-wise) to the different performers. I think the game is sterilized for unbalance, which of course protects it from being broken but in the same time makes it less fun. All in all a very good euro.
For the artwork: excellent illustration skills. I would like the informational icons to stand out more though. They blend in the colours of the illustration a bit too much.

item.name: Drum Roll: Mini Expansion
item.comment:
A good addition that mainly addresses the problem of trailers (they were not a good enough bonus imo) and offers some new interesting performers.
I would like to see an expansion that would attach BROKEN abilities to each different kind of performer. Drum roll is a great game but it's sterilized for unbalance, which I think hurts it rather than benefits it.

item.name: Drum Roll: Performer Promo Cards
item.comment: Nothing too essential, although they do offer some different strategy potential.

item.name: Drum Roll: Plate Spinner
item.comment: Very nice and different!

item.name: Drum Roll: Ringmaster
item.comment: A good promo. Boosts the mechanics a little bit further.

item.name: Duck, Duck, Bruce
item.comment: A generic push your luck card game. Fast and fun. A snack for push your luck fans.

item.name: Duel in the Dark
item.comment: This is one of those rare instances that I can't pinpoint what exactly is wrong with the game. By reading the manual it looks like a brilliant atmospheric WWII duel. By looking at the components and the art it looks amazing. However, it does not work as well as it looks. Altitude is a main issue that I can easily recognize: needed more work there, gameplay-wise. Apart from that, a mediocre light wargame.

item.name: Dune
item.comment: A nice and completely thematic area control game.Genius for its days(1979)

item.name: Dungeon Lords
item.comment: Exceptional game. Unique in its own kind. Exceptional artwork/components. It is tight though, feels a bit like agricola. Wish for some more rooms and a bit longer game.

item.name: Dungeon Lords: Festival Season
item.comment: Although this expansion does make the game easier by adding a 5th round, it actually does not contribute a major new mechanic, rather more content and small mini-mechanics which are not absolutely needed. Although it is not bad at all, it is not essential either. The best mini-mechanic I liked are the pets. The 5th round is a notion, it can be applied even without the expansion.

item.name: Dungeon Lords: Happy Anniversary
item.comment: Excellent production. Coins could have a better design though.

item.name: Dungeon Lords: Minions Bearing Gifts
item.comment:
I have played only the straightforward version: makes the game even harder, by boosting the adventurers' powers. However, it does offer a bit more balance, since the player who is ahead will probably receive the worst effect. Not an essential addition.
The tricky items version seems better.

item.name: Dungeon Petz
item.comment:
Ok. This is a good game. It reminds me of Drum roll, another economic game in which the financial aspect is hidden behind the richness of the theme. Actually these 2 games have more in common than meets the eye. The different abstract-coloured cubes/needs of the performers/animals is another similarity.
The best part in Petz is explaining the rules! after that, the first play is a bit introductory. On your second play you begin to realize the economic engine a bit better. It is a good game but not one that will have you jumping up and down from excitement. The choices are balanced and the theme is very rich. It is a perfectly fine semi-economic euro with many small innovations. The rules actually sound a lot harder than the gameplay really is. Its complexity is the same as Dungeon Lords, and its difficulty is lighter.

item.name: Dungeon Petz: Dark Alleys
item.comment: A nice expansion that adds a lot of content and variety, although the base game is sufficient by itself. Use for more variety.

item.name: Dungeon Roll
item.comment: A nice light push your luck dungeon-themed game. Would like it to last more.

item.name: Dungeon Run
item.comment: Some innovative dice mechanics, and great artwork, but it doesn't shine distinguishably amongst other dungeon crawlers.

item.name: Dungeon Twister
item.comment: A clever,skillfully designed abstract game.

item.name: DungeonQuest (third edition)
item.comment: Ha ha ha!I had some laughs with this one!Not of course to be taken seriously (as some other more strategic adventure games), however it has a nice flow. I enjoyed it. Bit afraid for the replaybality factor, however from what I hear from fans it isn't an issue.

item.name: Dungeons & Dragons: Castle Ravenloft Board Game
item.comment: For a SIMPLE,distilled dungeoncrawl with a good gameplay I would rate it a 10.For a complete dungeoncrawl experience,the rating goes down.Very good graphic design.Makes me not to mind about the missing artwork.The monster scripts could be more elaborate without adding to the complexity of the game.A good game,a nice effort if you need a shorter dungeoncrawl.

item.name: Dungeonville
item.comment: An easy and fun push your luck with an RPG theme. Wish there were more items, and I have some disagreements with the victory condition.

item.name: DVONN
item.comment: Although I hate abstract games,this one seems quite ok with deep strategies like backgammon.

item.name: The Dwarf King
item.comment: A beautifully illustrated trick taking game that has 3 suits, which makes it simpler, and variable scoring rules (like chronicle, but easier to achieve and thus more interesting). A trick taking game of choice. Only downside is that the cards are a weird size that is hard to sleeve.

item.name: Earth Reborn
item.comment: Must play more advanced scenarios to fully appreciate the game. I only played the simplest scenario (move+melee) and I am not enthusiastic about it. However I dislike the graphic design on the cards. Illustrations are good, and the cover is great. But the cards and all that info, they are badly presented. For that much info, the illustration and a simple numbered table with no icons at all would be better. Also, less satin effect and better color choices could be useful.

item.name: Eclipse
item.comment:
Excellent 4X space civ - area control - space conflict game. The rules are minimal but offer many strategies. A review of a lot of great ideas and balances, and some needed innovations. Great graphic design too. Eclipse has almost none of the flaws of Twilight Imperium (duration, hard to remember technology tree, bad micromanagement) and the great innovation of ship fitting. However there is no need to sell your Twilight Imperium copy, as TI remains an epic game.
After some plays, my only complaint is that there is a chaotic battle going on in the last 2 rounds that seems repetitive and not "in accord with the game's philisophy".

item.name: Eclipse: Rockets of Celebration
item.comment: This mini expansion adds a rather interesting and useful surprise in the mid game.

item.name: Eclipse: Ship Pack One
item.comment: Other than the most useful turn order variant which can be implemented easily without this expansion, it offers mainly a component upgrade which is not too essential, while the price is very high.

item.name: Egizia
item.comment:
Excellent eurogame with many mechanics, including end VP conditioning, permanent and immediate benefits, and many interesting balances. Nice one.
probably needed a bit more changes for the 2 player game, but still it plays well with 2.

item.name: Elasund: The First City
item.comment: Well... I didn't like it that much, although it's not a bad game. Less fun than Catan, of course. There is "take that" interaction and area influence which I did not like. There are different ways to score which I liked, but there is constant conflict which can get frustrating.

item.name: Elder Sign
item.comment: Very nice production. It has the feel of Arkham horror in a nutshell without being stupid. My biggest complaint is that it should be designed so all players have something to do simultaneously, to avoid downtime with 6 or more players. Another complaint is that I wished for more abilities on the items. Pretty nice mechanics overall! wouldn't mind if the dice rolling was a bit more complex. A more modern, up to date Arkham horror with less fiddling.

item.name: Elder Sign: Gates of Arkham
item.comment: A nice, more difficult setting in which to play elder sign. Skill cards are very nice. The trophy spending market has been replaced with opportunities in the back of the cards, which is a very nice mechanic.

item.name: Elder Sign: Unseen Forces
item.comment: An excellent expansion that not only adds content, but also improves the main game.

item.name: Eldritch Horror
item.comment: A very good addition to the genre. The rules and the mechanics are more elegant than arkham horror, while the gameplay remains in the same levels I think.

item.name: Elfenland
item.comment: A prefer this theme than trains! another network Alan Moon game, the gameplay is simple, an ok game, nothing special. Should be rank 1000+

item.name: Elysium
item.comment: A medium light euro with possibilities. Need more plays to judge how robust the game remains after many plays.

item.name: Eminent Domain
item.comment: A Race for the galaxy - Glory to Rome hybrid with a deck building element. Works well! A lot better the 2nd time you play it, when you have grasped the mechanics better. Excellent, probably one of the best graphic design results! Kudos to the graphic designers! An excellent 2nd game for mr Jaffee. Wish it lasted a bit longer. Would like expansions!

item.name: Eminent Domain: Bonus Planets
item.comment: A great addition to the base game, almost necessary.

item.name: Empire Engine
item.comment: Unfortunately I did not like anything about the game. Particularly, I disliked the way you choose actions, and the variety of actions offered.

item.name: The End of the Triumvirate
item.comment: A light area control game. Balanced, with constant conflict. I liked 3 ways to victory and the compensation factor when someone loses a territory. However did not enjoy the game much due to the constant back and forth conflict which I dislike in many area control games.

item.name: Endeavor
item.comment: A great euro/light civ/exploration game. Best innovative mechanic: You build your own choices for later rounds while playing. It works great. One of the medium euros of choice. Simplified gameplay with depth. After some plays: The game holds great depth and remains very entertaining to play. The balances and the choices ascend through the rounds and I see it as a beloved star in my collection.

item.name: Entdecker: Exploring New Horizons
item.comment: Clearly better than carcassonne.It is like carcassonne but with the exploration element.It could still be a better game.

item.name: Epic
item.comment: Played with the downloadable kickstarter content. Not as thrilled as with star realms and ascension (from the same designers). It seemed that I could not distinguish between cards - they all seemed to fluent and random, and thus I found difficulties in grasping the feel of the game.

item.name: Escape from the Aliens in Outer Space
item.comment: I like the pen and paper concept, the safe to dangerous areas, but the action could be tighter.

item.name: Escape: The Curse of the Temple
item.comment: A light dice rolling / real time coop game. It could be fun with the proper group, but the fuss created in many real time games will probably keep me from a 2nd play.

item.name: Euphoria: Build a Better Dystopia
item.comment: The game is a lighter version of troyes/tzolkin/alien frontiers with some innovations and a beautiful production. I found it a bit less challenging than those three, and considering its high price I would avoid it. I would play again but I have to say I expected more - it seemed dry. Gather this - to pay that - to get a vp, with no chances for serious engine building.

item.name: Evo
item.comment: Great theme incorporation,nice mechanics,although needed more game time to be perfect.I prefer Cyclades,although it still is a cute game.

item.name: Exodus: Proxima Centauri
item.comment: A lighter eclipse/twilight imperium hybrid. It is not bad. The production has minor flaws. The game has a fully available tech tree for each player that I very much liked. If you prefer a faster eclipse, this game's for you.

item.name: Fabula
item.comment: Storytelling game with a subjective master, much like Aye Dark Overlord, only with more components and one of the best artworks I've seen in game. The artwork is simply magnificient!!

item.name: Famiglia
item.comment: Another very underrated Friese light diamond! It seems almost as a point of reference to 2player light card games. Probably as good as Jaipur.

item.name: Family Business
item.comment: Meh. Like guillotine, but worse. Couldn't find any strategy at all. Don't have any idea why some people like it.

item.name: Fauna
item.comment: Great game!If translated in English it would be top 100.This is the game that you can play with any member of your family,gamer or non-gamer friends.Trivia and waging,with a very nice theme.Takes globalissimo to another level!Still there is room for improvement though,to make the perfect game.There could be more betting categories,like e.g. what the animals eat,how long they live etc.EXPANSION PLEASE!

item.name: Fauna: Eierlegende Wollmilchsau & Innerer Schweinehund Promo
item.comment: I don't get it. It's useless.

item.name: Fearsome Floors
item.comment: A pretty funny game, but as intrigue, I would not play it for a second time. It feels like an 80's computer game and the production is very funny, but replayability suffers I think.

item.name: Felix: The Cat in the Sack
item.comment: Many people enjoy this fast paced poker-feel game. Reminds me of some nasty greek poker variants, where cards are opened in sequence and you have to bid. It's nice. Could be even trickier I guess.

item.name: A Few Acres of Snow
item.comment:
Excellent! Uncle Martin did it again. The deck building element provides countless strategic possibilities which are also intuitive and in accordance with the theme. This is one of the best wargames I've played, along with Hannibal and Washington's war. The board lacks some needed visual aids (e.g. about what each location would yield) and it also confuses a bit about if some areas are connected or not, but it looks beautiful and it works fine. A great deal of strategies to try and explore. What an original use of the deck building mechanic in a wargame. This is the first and only of its kind!
Congratulations Mr. Wallace. you did it again.
edit: second play. my opinion has shifted dramatically to: excellent! (again :D ) each choice in this game is skillfully and subtly intertwined with every other thing. There won't be another one like it. It's not a trend.

item.name: Fictionaire
item.comment: A nice, simple party game in the footsteps of dixit and balderdash. Very compact and with less fuss, it is perfect for pic nics or instances with small or no table space.

item.name: Field of Glory: The Card Game
Fields of Arle
item.comment: Well, yes, it resembles other Uwe's agricola-clones, but it has the benefit of almost nonexistent round setup. It also has a steep learning curve since even experienced Uwe fans will find it confusing at the first play. Best feature is the action that lets you permanently boost your other actions.

item.name: Finca
item.comment: A good,fast and balanced euro.It kind of reminded me Cartagena in the strategy you use to gain fruit.Nothing too special or innovative though.

item.name: Five Tribes
item.comment: Lots of nice working mechanics and special abilities, although I believe that the spatial element and the meeple movement/placement destroys planning which hurts the game. On the other hand it enhances the use of bidding for turn order.

item.name: Fleet
item.comment: A very nice bidding game with abilities and interesting balances. Another game in this category is middle kingdom from tom lehmann.

item.name: Fleet: Arctic Bounty
item.comment: Adds variety but I would not call it a great addition mechanics-wise.

item.name: Flick 'em Up!
