item.comment: It's a fun game that looks great on the table, but unfortunately I could not find something especially interesting about it.

item.name: Florenza: The Card Game
item.comment: A nice and short development game with great graphic design (excellent resource cards). I would classify it with mundus novus that came out almost in the same time. The game seems balanced and fair.

item.name: For Sale
item.comment: Excellent! minimal rules-great depth and fun. Bidding excellence!

item.name: Forbidden Island
item.comment: One step further than pandemic (although simpler), this beautiful game (BRAVO to the publisher) is one of the few superlight coop games that I'd play.

item.name: Formula DÃ©
item.comment: An excellent and at the same time light racing simulation that works unexpectedly well! I place it among other exceptional racing games like snowtails, I even prefer it as it causes more laughs during a play.

item.name: Fort Boyard
item.comment: A party/dexterity game. It captures the atmosphere of the TV show. Which is not a good thing. It really needed MUCH MUCH thicker chits. Which is not a good thing. Many of the tasks are lame. Which is not a good thing.

item.name: Francis Drake
item.comment: Oh my. What a terrible theme. Anyhow, the game is good, but I was not ecstatic. The mechanics work well, the playtime is great, the art is wonderful but I wouldn't call it the game of the year. Perhaps a less expensive production would also be more appropriate.

item.name: Francis Drake: Montezuma's Legacy Expansion
item.comment: I don't think toying with the game balance would be good.

item.name: Francis Drake: Spain's Revenge Expansion
item.comment: Increases the difficulty a bit, which unexpectedly I think would work best for beginner players.

item.name: Freedom: The Underground Railroad
item.comment: Yes, this works perfectly! very light rules, yet deep gameplay. Perfect for abstract fans, for eurogame fans, and for card-driven games fans.

item.name: Freeze
item.comment: An acting game that could produce some laughs, but I would like it to be bit more intrusive in the player's performances. As is, a player's performance is only limited by the setting and the rank.

item.name: Fresco
item.comment: A fine thematic worker placement / resource upgrade game, only if played with all 3 modules of course. Much more preferred than pastiche which shares the same theme.

item.name: Friday
item.comment: This is an excellent gem! theme incorporation, mechanics, depth. Very enjoyable! Not sure about the test of time though. Will see! This is my ... by farthest fine fix by friend Friedemann Friese.

item.name: Friday the 13th
item.comment: It has some purpose,but not much

item.name: Funfair
item.comment: Yes. I can buy this as a party game. Although it could be even more fun, Friese has taken the first step in a novel direction for party games.

item.name: Funny Friends
item.comment: An ambitious thematic idea,but unfortunately the theme is incorporated only in the cards,while the game mechanics are very abstract.Maybe if the various traits had effects on your strategy or bestowed different abilities the gameplay would be better.Anyhow,can be a great game if the group supports it.Exceptional minimalistic artwork.

item.name: FÃ¼rstenfeld
item.comment: A mini development game.The demand reduction mechanism is needed by the game,but it is not at its best.There could be a more fulfilling mechanism. An ok game overall.

item.name: Fury of Dracula (second edition)
item.comment:
ÎŸne of the few games to use the "hidden movement on map" mechanic, like letters from whitechapel, nuns on the run, scotland yard, escape from the aliens in outer space, etc.
This one is the ameritrash version, featuring combat and more twists. The hunt works well.

item.name: Futterneid
item.comment: Depending on the mood and the party, it could be from boring to fun fun fun! I would rather prefer it played with actual candies as it is suggested in the manual. You can see the theme in the game, other than that it is pretty light and simple.

item.name: Galaxy Trucker
item.comment: Very nice ideas.I wished for more development that would boost a feeling of continuance through the rounds.Special award tiles for the players that accomplished things in the 1st round.Pay credits in order to get tiles.Combat between players could be a fun component as long as it didn't affect the scoring much.But still,it's another gem by my favorite designer.

item.name: Galaxy Trucker: Rough Road Ahead
item.comment: Yes, it increases difficulty. But does it increase strategy? not sure.

item.name: Galaxy Trucker: The Big Expansion
item.comment: Excellent expansion! even better than the base game! must have if you enjoy Galaxy trucker! all missing intuitive features are present!

item.name: Gambit 7
item.comment: Better questions than Wits & Wagers, for european people, but way worse components.

item.name: A Game of Thrones (first edition)
item.comment: One of the few area control games I like. It is balanced, it provides control and strategy is not chaotic. Which is quite an achievement for a game that relies on diplomacy so much. It is one of the good ones. If you like area control games it is a must. Very much like the different combat cards and probably it's one of the few games that have 1 to 1 force comparison combat that I like. However I would deny another play because I think it takes up a lot of time. Ports addition are a must. You can pretend they exist and save yourself the cost of the expansion.

item.name: A Game of Thrones: A Clash of Kings Expansion
item.comment: Ports are a must. Good overall expansion, although I haven't played with 6 players.

item.name: A Game of Thrones: The Board Game (Second Edition)
item.comment: Better than the first ed. with some needed add-ons from the 1st ed. expansions. I'll repeat that this is a perfectly good area control wgame with a major cutthroat-backstabbing element. I do not like area control games, and I definitely avoid backstabbing games, so I will not play this again. That does not make it a bad game. Just my taste. I rated 9.

item.name: Game of Thrones: The Card Game
Gargon
item.comment: Another conventional trick taking game that has nothing to offer.

item.name: Gears of War: The Board Game
item.comment: The best of its kind. Ecstatic.

item.name: Gem Rush
item.comment: A very nice game, it felt more like a solo game, and the ultralight mechanic is not analogous to the depth. This really could have been an even bigger production, there is potential in the simple 2 gems per card mechanic. I am thinking that if the cost for a room was proportionate to the room's ability (instead of random), the game would climb very high.

item.name: Genesis
item.comment: Ok, granted, it has some meaning but it is too simple without substantial depth. Feels like a promising project left incomplete. "God" should have intervened here.

item.name: Genoa
item.comment: The first minutes of the game were pure fun and laughs! it does not miss out in strategy, but it could last less time. Our 4p game took about 3 hours to complete. Its main idea seems to work ok, thus the high rating. Goa is also a good choice.

item.name: Get Nuts
item.comment: Pointless back and forth with simple but pointless interaction filler. Nice graphic design. I can see what the designer wanted to accomplish, but he should take it a step further.

item.name: Gheos
item.comment: A carcassonne-civilization themed alternative. Very nice "at will" scoring mechanism and after 1-2 plays you learn not to be overthrown that easily.

item.name: Ghooost!
item.comment: A different trick taking game which feels like it works backwards. Not bad. Hard to grasp at first play.

item.name: Ghost Blitz
item.comment: Like set, but with actual items. One of the best minimals in its kind (among set, jungle speed, dobble, etc)

item.name: Ghost Stories
item.comment: A non boring coop game that actually works and is replayable with a nicely given fantasy theme.

item.name: Giants
item.comment: A very nice euro. It has many classical balances found in lots of euros but it is very nicely tied up and there are a lot of finely balanced choices to make, like development or rush. Add up the component quality and you have a very nice euro.

item.name: GiftTRAP
item.comment: A nice party game that aspires to bring you closer with your friends.Ideal for non gamers!

item.name: GiftTRAP Geek Edition
item.comment: They could be even better.

item.name: Ginkgopolis
item.comment: Compact rules and excellent artwork deliver a fast paced city building game with development and nice choices. Seems like an evolution of older succesful area influence/city building/tile placement euros.

item.name: Glass Road
item.comment: A very good mechanic on the wheel regarding the production of the higher level resources. Other than that, at the first play it seems like a good abstraction of other Rosenberg games. The fact that the game is relatively short does not contribute to the gaming experience in comparison with Uwe's caverna that was released simultaneously. However, if you are looking for a short family game with interaction and depth, this game is for you.

item.name: Glen More
item.comment:
Excellent! a better cuba. Wish for cuba's components though. What a great game for this simplicity. Want to play again to judge replayability.
edit: replayability ok so far (7 plays)

item.name: Globalissimo
item.comment: For its purpose(light family trivia game),I rate it a 9, comparable to Fauna. I enjoyed playing it as it triggers conversation and it features a very nice gamble mechanic.

item.name: Gloom
item.comment: A promising transparency mechanic, a great theme and fluff text, but the shallow depth of the game does not counter its simplistic gameplay. You could a lot more with these components.

item.name: Glory to Rome
item.comment: Clever mechanics.A lighter,alternative race for the galaxy?Each card is used in various ways.Unique and very fulfilling.I wished for more buildings!It provides a very deep gaming experience in a simple and fast play.

item.name: The Gnomes of Zavandor
item.comment: Another beuatifully illustrated light economic game from the Zavandor series. The game is better than what its rank implies.

item.name: Go Wild!
item.comment: A trick taking game with some balance. Nothing much more to offer though.

item.name: Goa
item.comment: Excellent euro!the bidding mechanic is incorporated well and fast. The various tiles are a marvellous sight as you plan you strategies. I agree with user 3pod (artipia games, drum roll) in that I'd like a semi-variant development cost that differs between players. Wishlisted! but why is a rank#27 game out of print? come on, Hans Im Gluck / Rio grande games!

item.name: Goblins, Inc.
item.comment: A nice, fast, funny, lighter galaxy trucker.

item.name: Goldland
item.comment: With 1 play,it just seemed "change this to that",random enough to take the fun out of the exploration element,as the main problems is that all regions have the same "character".Change this to that resource.It would have great potential if the tiles were a lot more distinguishable from eachother.

item.name: GOSU
item.comment: Main mechanic is nice alright but I wanted less or smarter interaction and/or smarter card abilities. It's an ok game but it does not reach the depthe of Race fot the Galaxy.

item.name: Granada
item.comment: A simple and quick set collection/tile placement game.

item.name: Grand Cru
item.comment: An economic game, a simulation of a vineyard. It provides a robust production/economy system and many interesting choices. I like the many different development choices. Would like to play again!

item.name: El Grande
item.comment: I love the different actions that come up each round,although i don't like territory control games,because kingmakers ruin them all the time.

item.name: La Granja
item.comment: An excellent design! The game is initially hard without the artificial obligation to feed or pay something every couple of rounds, which requires skill on part of the designer. It plays well, it is balanced. And as a bonus, there is a very nicely working card utilisation mechanic. I have a concern about how critical the initial helpers are. Overall a great euro.

item.name: La Granja: 2nd Edition Promo Cards
item.comment: Nice pack that adds variety.

item.name: The Great Dalmuti
item.comment: A clever card game that is not low on the fun side!

item.name: Great Wall of China
item.comment: One of many typical medium quality Knizia games.

item.name: Greed
item.comment: Would work even better if the interaction were more streamlined and the graphic design I think also doesn't help. Other than that, could be characterized as a reference card drafting game with "take that" interaction.

item.name: Guillotine
item.comment: Very nice artwork and non gamer groups seem to enjoy it very much. One of the most known light card games.

item.name: Hacienda
item.comment: A very nice tile placement. I hate this genre however I enjoyed playing this particular game, because of the various generous choices that it offers.

item.name: Hamburgum
item.comment: A basic rondel game. Not the best one. Less development, more opportunistic. I prefer Antike and Navegador. I also think a more elegant market system escapes Gerdts for some time now. I advise you to prefer another Gerdts rondel game like imperial, antike or navegador.

item.name: Hanabi
item.comment: Excellent idea. Everyone else can see your cards instead of you! probably one of the coop fillers of choice!

item.name: HÃ¤ndler der Karibik
item.comment: A very nice light filler with abilities. The endgame condition finds me somewhat opposed.

item.name: Hands Up
item.comment: A reflex game that is harder than what it looks. Eye-to-hand coordination is the main mechanic, and much depends on the referee. It's ok if you want some laughs.

item.name: Hannibal: Rome vs. Carthage
item.comment: One of the good wargames I've played.Exceptional battle system that captures the uncertainty,the balance of forces,and other aspects of battle with a rather simple but on-the-spot mechanism!I like the retreat rules also.The board is exquisite,I like the puzzle lock production,but I have two observations.The provinces should be depicted with slightly variant colours so they are more distinguishable,and the board should have a provinces track for easy keeping of political influence differences.Gameplay-wise,I love the balancing mechanisms (e.g. winter attrition) but I still do not find the game crystal perfect.Clearly preferrable to Twilight Struggle.

item.name: Hansa
item.comment: A simplistic reference opportunistic trading game. Not bad. Not exciting.

item.name: Hansa Teutonica
item.comment: Excellent euro! truly balanced between ability building and direct scoring. A masterpiece of what a simple euro can be.

item.name: Hansa Teutonica: East Expansion
item.comment: A very interesting map, not entirely different experience, but with good balances.

item.name: Harbour
item.comment: Trying to boost interaction made the market too chaotic. Spending an action to manipulate the market only finds you a round later randomly helping other players and still not at the position you recently tried to build. Having only 4 buildings as game end condition hurts the development aspect of the game. The game seemed to have a good base, but trying to make it lighter perhaps hurt it.

item.name: Hart an der Grenze
item.comment: Nice bluffing filler.Not very boring for its simplicity

item.name: Havana
item.comment: It features the beautiful artwork of Menzel's Cuba, but it is a very simplistic euro. There are 4 buildings available to build if you gather the needed materials. Buildings do not have abilities, they just score vp. In your turn, you refresh one of your 2 played cards and follow their action, which would be take/steal X materials. Pretty simplistic. Not my choice. Looks like the beginning of a promising game that was left undeveloped.

item.name: Le Havre
item.comment: Excellent, strategic and balanced, the best resource management game I've played! Love the many buildings, after 1-2 plays they become intuitive. PS Mr Rosenberg,I think the tannery should be 5x.

item.name: Le Havre: Le Grand Hameau
item.comment: A must-have addition! Almost all of them are excellent.

item.name: Le Havre: The Inland Port
item.comment: A lovable compact resource management game. It has something of Le Havre, and a bit from roll through the ages. It also seems deep enough. Have to play more!

item.name: Hawaii
item.comment: A euro with interesting choices and very fun to play!

item.name: Heads of State
item.comment:
One of the worst Z-man productions. Yes I loved the many scoring mechanics and the wooden counters, but the graphic design and the treachery cards ruin the game. The graphic design actually makes the game impossible to play. You can't tell the colours or the nobles apart and it is very frustrating looking at the map of europe.
The worst graphic design I have ever seen in a game.

item.name: Heimlich & Co.
item.comment: This is a mechanic, not a game. For a mechanic, it's good. For a game, incomplete.

item.name: Helios
item.comment: A respectable euro with an innovative mechanic that rewards small and compact tile placement in contrast with asymmetric expansion that yields other kinds of profit. A nice game overall, it is a medium complexity / medium duration euro. I would like a more intricate mechanic regarding the drafting of the leaders.

item.name: HeroQuest
item.comment: Try Descent. For its time though it was top!

item.name: History of the World
item.comment: Well it has many mechanics that were afterwards copied by many good games, but I don't like the way the expand action is carried. Excellent production and nice board, but nowadays there are other, better games of this kind. Struggle of Empires is one. I am also missing the civ element feel.

item.name: Hive
item.comment: A faster chess?

item.name: Hochstapler
item.comment: Well, it's nothing special mechanics-wise, but for its purpose it's an ok game, fast and fun. I wish there could be some extra source of information for the players, apart from which card they hold.

item.name: Hoity Toity
item.comment: One of the best "old" games I've played. The mechanic works well for its age. Drafting by bidding, and bluffing. Not too good if you lose both of your thieves :). Pretty nice overall. Could have some final touches that make it even better but can't complain, regarding its age.

item.name: Horus Heresy
item.comment: This wargame offers an innovative combat mechanic that allows for some serious experience and skill to kick in.

item.name: Hyperborea
item.comment: A eurotrash that light tactics fans will love. It introduces many new mechanics, and it lasts a small amount of time in comparison to other light civ games. I would prefer if the civ element was accentuated in favor of the fighting element, and I wouldn't mind if the game lasted longer with the main emphasis on development and less focus in conflict.

item.name: I'm the Boss!
item.comment: It's fun! you laugh. Deal striking-instant negotiation madness and fun. Depends on the players though. This game 'screams' Sid Sackson!

item.name: Igels: Das Kartenspiel
item.comment: Promising artwork and idea. The gameplay needed some small change in the way you select which animals to fight each round.

item.name: Illuminati: Deluxe Edition
item.comment: The tile money and the place-money-on-cards mechanic ruin the gameplay.But it has great incorporated theme,each card is different,and I play the variant with the very nice hidden goals.It would get a 9.8 if the money were plastic or wooden easily identifiable tokens.

item.name: Im Auftrag des KÃ¶nigs
item.comment: A nice pocket-size game, there are various actions to pick from but I'm afraid it tends to be simplistic and repetitive after some plays.

item.name: Imperial
item.comment:
Well. I disagree that this is his best game. Though, this game is perfect for you if you like abstract wargames with heavy economic elements, like in 18XX. In my first play, I tried the "no flag" strategy, taking as many interest and investing frequently. The game is a great design that mixes as perfect as possible the area control of abstract wargames and the commodity speculation of games with shares and investing.
I dislike area control, and did not enjoy this game much, in contrast with some other "more civilized" area control games that I prefer.
However I recommend it to anyone that likes the genre.

item.name: Imperial Settlers
item.comment: An interesting example of a game that has nothing wrong going on with it, has excellent production, illustrations and graphic design, and yet feels like it is missing something that I cannot pinpoint. Perhaps it needed to restrict the players more. I concur with JamesH that the cards needed staging. A good and short game overall that takes very little time to explain.

item.name: In the Shadow of the Emperor
item.comment: A promising area influence euro, however the constant power changes bother me. I like the different actions and the election system but I did not enjoy the game enough.

item.name: In the Year of the Dragon
item.comment:
Very nice mechanics, greatly strategic and balanced game, love the vp per round mechanism. A must for experienced gamers, although there is no WOW factor at the first plays.
Probably one of the most replayable games, with proper gameplay even for tournaments. Menzel should also do the inside of the game! This is probably the game with the largest distance between gameplay and production quality. A deluxe version is wanted!

item.name: Incan Gold
item.comment: Another excellent light game from Fred's bookshelf series. Hilarious push your luck gameplay, and with the extra feature of artifacts it becomes even better than its predecessor, diamant. 8 players can play this, so it's a must have!

item.name: Indonesia
item.comment: Excellent! a bit of brass, a bit of steam, an economic game of medium complexity that rewards the time invested in it. In terms of how easy time passes while playing, I compare it to through the ages! it is an excellent economic game that does not burn your mind, yet it provides a full developing network building - resource producing - stock handling experience. Recommended!

item.name: Industria
item.comment: A clever minimalist auction game that actually works and holds some strategy and depth! Great artwork!

item.name: Infarkt
item.comment: Yeah, well, although the theme is a hilarious hit, the gameplay itself is just balancing back and forth through various tracks, while the game pushes you forward, and the cards you play/actions you do push you backwards. It seems a bit pointless and tiring. Should be more tight. It gets kind of boring and replayability hurts.

item.name: Infinite City
item.comment: A typical tile placement game with a few twists and exceptional artwork and production quality. As for its strategy...pretty back and forth and opportunistic. I'd like more ways to secure my choices.

item.name: Infinite City: Guild Hall and Salvage Yard
item.comment: Nothing too essential.

item.name: Ingenious
item.comment: All my friends like it,but I don't.For an abstract game it is not what I would prefer.It is good though.Love the fact that you score based on your worst category.

item.name: Inkognito: The Card Game
item.comment: A light deduction and interaction game. The game works, and it is ultra fast, but I am not sure it was that fun.

item.name: Inn-Fighting
item.comment: The dice mechanism is not so bad but I'd like more choices. The characters are great!

item.name: Innovation
item.comment: Another masterpiece from Carl! innovative mechanics, many strategies to explore. Many people are bothered by the game flow that seems a bit random and fluctuating, but after some plays I am sure that this will not bother me. The game design is brilliant: it's not just a few new mechanics! the way the abilities are spread through each color and each era is completely balanced. Card abilities offer many combos "invisible to the naked eye". Although yes, the flow could be a bit more persistent.

item.name: Instinct
item.comment: A simple trick taking game that follows the norm, no twist. Nice artwork.

item.name: Intrigue
item.comment: With the correct group,it can be a lot of fun!Lots of laughs for everyone in the first play! I see it as a party game...

item.name: La Isla
item.comment: Another nice light Feld game, with the proper feel and the proper balance. I particularly like the mechanic of keeping benefits between rounds and building your scoring mechanic. Wish this was a larger game.

item.name: Isla Dorada
item.comment: Very nice family bidding game with many special effects cards, many different cards and EXCELLENT production value! fun to play! strategically it's not excellent but it is fun. And the artwork is magnificient.

item.name: Istanbul
item.comment: A good euro that combines succesfully many present mechanics, thus giving a fresh feeling without engaging in any groundbreaking innovations.

item.name: It Happens..
item.comment: Probably only Feld could come up with a light euro that packs that much strategy with so compact rules. Could be better of course, but still it stands.

item.name: It's Alive!
item.comment: A bidding game that tries to be thematic.

item.name: J'te Gage Que...
item.comment: Great idea, not so great tasks.

item.name: Jaipur
item.comment: A great ultra light trading game for 2. One of the best games for 2 in that complexity. Only thing that worried me is the market population mechanic.

item.name: Jamaica
item.comment: Excellent!one of the best family games I've played!More ship upgrades that you could pay for,would make it a great game!

item.name: Jamaica: Extra Treasures
item.comment: Useful but small.

item.name: Jambo
item.comment: Nice game! Very beautifully illustrated. Many different abilities that can be used wisely. This should be one of my reference resource management games with many different abilities. I must try the expansion also.

item.name: John Silver
item.comment: An easy filler. Nothing too special.

item.name: Journey to the Center of the Earth
item.comment: A nice exploration, a lot better than adventurers,with tools that actually do different interesting things and treasure gathering mechanism that is more interesting than tikal.It should be higher in rank.

item.name: Jungle Speed
item.comment: A simple catch-it-first game. Fun for some. Blood on hands is not uncommon.

item.name: Junta
item.comment: This is a great game with great mechanics for its time that work well even today. However the coup part with the area control element makes the game too long and shallow each time, although for its time it could be a breakthrough. Today it just needs a super fast mechanic to handle the coup progression without having to move units around (simple bidding would be nice).

item.name: Junta: Viva el Presidente!
item.comment: Yes! at last, the good mechanics of the original Junta, but without the great fluff. Nice party - negotiation game, with the theme of a light political satire.

item.name: K2
item.comment: Nice concept, but too light I'm afraid. It's hard alright, but too light for my taste.

item.name: Kaispeicher
item.comment: One of the most essential expansions for a game, that addresses -but does not fully correct- some issues I had with the base game, particularly regarding many workers placed in vain. It is a pity because the base game was an almost "must-buy" for me. I would only recommend the game to be played with this expansion!

item.name: Kaleidos
item.comment: A simple observation/speed party game. You have to try and find words that start with a specific letter, in a very complex image, in a limited amount of time. that's it.

item.name: Keltis
item.comment: Yeah, it's a very nice game. However it is a clone of other Knizia games (Lost cities, Lost cities boardgame, Keltis kartenspiele) and they are all one good game. I like this version also.

item.name: Keltis: Das Kartenspiel
item.comment: Feels a tad better than lost cities. I have to wag my finger to the Doc for making similar games but this is a very good filler.

item.name: Kemet
item.comment: A perfectly good example of a "eurotrash" game - a genre just between euro and ameritrash games. Reminded me in that way of Cyclades, although they share little in common mechanics-wise. It is a perfectly good game, I loved the tile ability-drafting system. However it forces you to conflict a lot more than Cyclades, which is not my cup of tea. Still a great game, with overproduced components.

item.name: Keyflower
item.comment: A good bidding/resource management euro with a spatial element. There is some innovation in the bidding mechanic. A light resource management game. I did not like the fact that the opponents can dictate which kind of workers are needed to activate your own actions, but there are ways to compensate. Not perfect, but good overall.

item.name: Keyflower: The Farmers
item.comment: It's an ok expansion, introducing the animals, which reminds me a lot of agricola. While a not bad expansion, I didn't feel it radically changed something about the game, neither that it added much variety. Best mechanic are the updated turn order tiles which also offer a gold.

item.name: Keythedral
item.comment: Pretty nice strategy that resembles Catan,theme that resembles Pillars,but terrible artwork that ruins the feel.Only the worker tiles are kinda nice.

item.name: King Arthur: The Card Game
item.comment: A bit like before the wind. Change something into a currency, and then use that currency for VPs.

item.name: King of Tokyo
item.comment: Something like "Roll through the ages" and "to court the king". The illustrations are great, and the gameplay supports the dice abilities and the push your luck element robustly. Wish the dice were smaller though so one could hold them easily in his hand. Simplicity is on the correct level- a bit less complicated and it would be stupid, a bit more and probably it would lose its fast style. A nice game!

item.name: King of Tokyo: Power Up!
item.comment: It does give certain flavour to the different monsters, however I expected something even more impressive. A good (?) thing is that it does not raise the difficulty level at all.

item.name: Kingdom Builder
item.comment: Excellent! one of my abstract games of choice! not boring at all. The best of its kind. It is also superlight.

item.name: Kingsburg
item.comment: Pretty original mechanic the dice placed on the board,but some strategies are better than others. Gotta have the expansion to shine, and still replayability suffers. Excellent board -nice game overall.

item.name: Kingsburg: To Forge a Realm
item.comment: A must have expansion,particularly if you find that the main game is lacking something you can't put your finger on.I would not trade away my game if I owned this expansion. The only module I dislike are the events, and the most useful modules are the added strength tokens (which could be emulated with components from other games) and the building updates.

item.name: Knights
item.comment: Nice idea, like this type of dice games. However I prefer the much more expensive "to court the king".

item.name: Kobayakawa
item.comment: An excellent ultralight game in the footsteps of for sale, but with different mechanics.

item.name: KÃ¶nig von Siam
item.comment: A minimalistic area control with some depth and nice mechanics. I could not manage to grasp the full depth with 1 play but I can't see how it could rate above 7.

item.name: KrakÃ³w 1325 AD
item.comment: Disappointing. The production is excellent (Z-man like I would say), and the artwork and fluff are very enjoyable. The game does try to offer something new to tricktaking games by letting the players place cubes on some goals, however the trick taking mechanic itself is quite boring, simplistic and non innovative, to the point I would say this is the worst trick taking mechanic game I've played. Feels like the game needed 6 more months of developing. Balances are ok, but the main mechanic offers very limited strategy.

item.name: Krakow 1325 AD: 3-player expansion
item.comment: I am sure this expansion does not offer any mechanic at all to improve the game for 3 players. As a matter of fact I think it offers nothing.

item.name: Kremlin
item.comment: Hilarious fluff text in a chaotic political mayhem game. This game features many serious mechanics for its age, or for today, even. However long term planning from AP players should be discouraged here. I dare say I could only play this as a fun party game, although it is clear it's not one. This combination of political medium-heavy rules and chaotic-party game results was not well accepted.

item.name: Kreta
item.comment: A nice balanced area influence euro,that has nothing too impressive to offer.Inefficent card design provides no clues as to what each character does,although it is easy to remember.

item.name: Kuhhandel Master
item.comment: A pretty nice auction game. Not sure if I prefer it from the vanilla version.

item.name: The Ladies of Troyes
item.comment: A nice addition. The extra die that cannot be stolen, and the various extra action cards are needed additions! the sentry is not bad either.

item.name: Lady Alice
item.comment: There is a good main deduction mechanic, but the player choices could be a lot deeper. Pity.

item.name: Lancaster
item.comment: A fast and deep development euro with some interaction. Characteristic of the game is the small duration in relation to its depth.

item.name: Lascaux
item.comment: Basic bidding game, did not find any flaws-apart from the fat that the animals all look alike- but also did not find any excitement either. Bidding mechanic reminds me of For sale, but the latter is better.

item.name: Last Night on Earth: The Zombie Game
item.comment: Nice and compact/fast ameritrash zombie fest.Betrayal At house on the hill though is also simple,but better in eveery aspect.

item.name: Last Train to Wensleydale
item.comment: Pick up and deliver / opportunistic network building. Your rails must be sold immediately after use in most of the cases in order to avoid costs. It is an ok game, I did not enjoy it as much as other Wallace games, partly due to its opportunistic nature. I also did not like the bidding categories very much. It could be a better game if you built your advancement in the 4 tracks instead of buying it each round. anyhow.

item.name: Last Will
item.comment: A pretty nice light economic euro with great theme and graphics. I'd wish for a more deep mechanic though, with more card interaction and broken combos.

item.name: Lawless
item.comment: It is surprising how better this game is from what you can figure out when buying it.

item.name: League of Six
item.comment:
One of the good bidding games. Simple with depth, if you are not a micromanager and would like some strategic but not competitive play (some info is hidden, which would be my choice as well).
With the expansion which offers extra abilities, the game skyrockets!

item.name: League of Six: Loyal Retinue
item.comment: EXCELLENT expansion! just what this game needed! MUST HAVE if you own league of six. It offers a 6th player and many strategic abilities.

item.name: Legacy: The Testament of Duke de Crecy
item.comment: I have played the prototype. The game looks like an innovative euro, however I felt that it was too tiring to create a pool of abilities that the various characters offer. Other than this gameplay disadvantage, I think the game is an ok euro. I would consider buying the game if it were a bit easier to bring abilities into my family tree. I would not like the gameplay in general to be easier, so I would direct the game's difficulty to other aspects.

item.name: Legendary: A Marvel Deck Building Game
item.comment: Resembles Ascension, which is the best deck building I've tried so far. It lacks the best feature (constructs), but offers different goals and scenarios. I would like a pristine graphic design. I think the symbols could be more distinct. I wouldn't mind if the comic book feel were reduced.

item.name: Legendary: Dark City
item.comment: A nice addition to the base game. Adds variety and a few new mini-mechanics. The only elementary change is the unique bystanders. The cards feel better than these of the vanilla game.

item.name: Legendary: Fantastic Four
item.comment: A nice addition to the base game. Adds variety and a few new mini-mechanics.The cards feel better than these of the vanilla game.

item.name: Legends of Andor
item.comment: Unfortunately not better than robinson crusoe, and it got out at the same time. It seems a perfectly wonderful family coop game, with less depth than robinson but still a good game and wonderfully produced. I expected perhaps some new impressive mechanics, but I did enjoy it. The gameplay decision level reminded me of Knizia's lord of the rings. I only played the introductory scenario, looking forward to another game.

item.name: Leonardo da Vinci
item.comment: A nice game that looks older than it is. It shares the worker placement mechanic with stone age. It is a development game with interesting choices, but I wish the different inventions had more individual character. A nice economic-euro overall.

item.name: Letters from Whitechapel
item.comment: An AREA deduction game, with a secret pen & paper movement mechanic, like "Escape from the Aliens in outer space". I like the artwork. It is playable, but nothing too exciting. The bad guy is moving secretly after being exposed by performing a series of murders. Each night he has to return to his hideout. The police are trying to place themselves optimally so they either capture him or they deduce out where his hideout is so they can block his way on a later round.

item.name: Lewis & Clark
item.comment: Yes, the game features a combination of mechanics that render it intuition-resistant (meaning: innovative) even to experienced players. The art in the board and the cards is beautiful. However, I found it difficult to enjoy the game itself. Many of the mechanics boil down to the race element and the random appearance of some cards.

item.name: Libertalia
item.comment: A light short, fun family game that support many players. Main strategical choice is in which order to play your hand. I think with some extra choices it could be even deeper, although the characters all seem useful and well playtested.

item.name: LibertÃ©
item.comment: Mmmh. It's the worst Wallace game I've played. There are lots of solid and balanced mechanics but overall it seemed a bit pointless back and forth in certain areas:I'll influence this area, you'll influence that, then I'll cancel your influence, then you'll cancel mine, then we draw cards again, and start all over. It needed something extra on the main mechanic to tie all the good mechanics together. I like the different victory conditions and the votes' balance on the cards.

item.name: Lifeboat
item.comment: It was quite fun at the first play but I'm not sure about replayability. I don't like the deterministic way combat is handled. Nice card quality, nice ideas.

item.name: Lifeboats
item.comment: I prefer Intrigue,it's funnier

item.name: Lifetime
item.comment: An ok trivia game with some strategy. Can be played easily in other languages as well.

item.name: Ligretto
item.comment: Hehehe. Light dexterity/observation game madness! but it gets repetitive fast.

item.name: Little Devils
item.comment: Indeed it is very funny. I dislike trick taking games, but I will play this many times.

item.name: London
item.comment:
A magnificient, more compatible, less weird, but all Wallace game, with artwork this time :) and Wallace classic balance, with beautiful mechanics that tie in with the theme. Draft, combos, tight decisions- all in just above 1 hour. The game deserves a 10 and it will never fall. Cards are slightly different in print but tremendously so in play. At least 3-4 plays needed to appreciate and grasp the game. I was lucky to get it with the first one.
Wallace owed himself such a game. It deserves top 30 rank definetely. Congratulations sir!
edit: Out of curiosity I've read the comments of some users that rated this game low, and I agree with most of their observations. However I find these observations good rather than bad. A matter of taste obviously. I like Race for the Galaxy and the vp machine you can create by utilising cards. Race is my 2nd best game after Through the ages. London is the 5th best game I've played.

item.name: Loony Quest
item.comment: A nice new mechanic, and cool graphics that resemble a platform computer game. However the mechanic does not leave much room for depth.

item.name: Looting London
item.comment: A light fast card game with a twist at the end.

item.name: The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game
item.comment: After some plays: not a bad game at all. A lot of hard strategic choices. I think the strategy maintains the stability of a board game without interference from the collectible aspect of the game. This is a constant development struggle game. Both sides are competing in the development, and the card mechanics offer deep strategies. I dislike the scoring rule that forces you to an early victory though. Apart from that, excellent.

item.name: The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game â€“ Conflict at the Carrock
item.comment: Contains some useful cards and a tricky adventure. Nice one.

item.name: The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game â€“ Heirs of NÃºmenor
item.comment: I tried an extra hard scenario here. Also, it contains many useful cards that perform excellent utility combos with previous ones.

item.name: The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game â€“ The Hobbit: Over Hill and Under Hill
item.comment: Thematic scenarios! Love the card-goals that are inherited to the next scenario. But, I would expect some more player cards.

item.name: The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game â€“ The Massing at Osgiliath
item.comment: One of the hardest scenarios, with intense fighting and threat rising. A desperate challenge.

item.name: Lord of the Rings: The Confrontation (Deluxe Edition)
item.comment: A great short stratego-like 2p game with balanced and interesting character abilities. Very strategic.

item.name: Lord of the Rings: The Search
item.comment: Nice exploration 2p tile game.

item.name: Lords of Waterdeep
item.comment: An excellent production of a reference worker placement game! 10 years before this game would probably be the #1 in Rank. It combines various well-known worker placement mechanics with a beautiful board, box and components, and it delivers very good gameplay! Could be even more strategic I think but I really enjoyed it.

item.name: Lords of Waterdeep: Inevitable Betrayal Promo Card
item.comment: Exactly the kind of dumb interaction I'd not like to see in a game. It's a good think the rest of the intrigue cards follow a different philosophy.

item.name: Lords of Waterdeep: Scoundrels of Skullport
item.comment: While the expansion is not at all bad, I expected more than one new mechanic for this production. Having said that, the corruption mechanic is a very good economic addition to the game.

item.name: Lost Cities
item.comment: Very nice and simple. One of Knizia's best.

item.name: Louis XIV
item.comment: Nice euro,but it feels like something is missing.

item.name: Love Letter
item.comment: Very nice hyperlight filler with secret roles and bluff as the main mechanic. I would like it just a tad heavier, not more. Perhaps one more strategy/ability?

item.name: Luna
item.comment: At last, a quality production in comparison with the other good Feld games.Luna is not better that Macao,Im Jahr des Drachen,Notre dame, but it is one of Feld's games. GODS, why the production on the previous ones was so poor? About the gameplay:I find Luna a bit abstract,particularly inside the monastery but I like the different abilities of the resources. Excellent visual result and overall artwork. It is an action management game, you try to do the most things with the less transfer actions. Pretty original mechanism but not that much fun.

item.name: Lysistrata
item.comment: As always, a thematic game from Cimino, with many interesting mechanics. There are 2 things I didn't enjoy in the game: first, the random card placement in some conflicts, and second, the continuous drafting seemed frustrating at times that despite the 4 options I could not get a card I wanted. Other than that this game is in a very good path, offering several card abilities and 2 different ways to win.

item.name: Macao
item.comment: A fresh mechanism,a balanced euro,replayability and fun very high due to many cards and combos.I would pay more for a DELUXE EDITION with better components and unique artwork for the cards. Most of the text on the cards could be symbolic. Feld's finest for me. A very deep game that takes many plays to fully appreciate.

item.name: Machi Koro
item.comment: The game handles interaction very skillfully. Other than that, I didn't find the abilities of the cards that interesting. Most strategic choices regard the card's activation number.

item.name: Madeira
item.comment:
Well it is almost impossible to judge this game properly with 1 play. It seems that the ratio between the increased complexity compared and the depth/gameplay potential it provides, falls just below my personal limit. I mean, this game seems overloaded with mechanics, even for heavy games fans like me. None of the mechanics seems clearly excessive, but after a point one wonders if they make the game better than it would be with 1-2 mechanics less.
What would happen if it had 1-2 mechanics less? well then the game is great! it is well designed, unique in its strategy. Would I play it again though? perhaps I would give it another chance, but consider that I am a fan of heavy games (mage knight, le havre etc) and I was not ecstatic with this one.

item.name: Mage Knight Board Game
item.comment:
An excellent adventure game, and by far the best there is! A vivid world is offered for exploration; the main mechanic of the game offers great possibilities. Many ways to utilize your cards and your mana make for plentiful strategies and depth. Each round is both a beautiful puzzle and a small decision. Brilliant! colourful! The game is also excellent as an adventure game that realises its creative fantasy world through both theme and mechanics. A must have for every boardgamer. In the expansion I'd like even more enemies, complex wounds, and most needed are new map tiles with even more new features to make the world of mage knight really vast.
edit: I am now convinced that Vlaada Chvatil is an advanced alien that has come to astonish us with his innovations, though instead of inventing the cure for cancer, the bastard makes boardgames!

item.name: Mage Knight Board Game: Krang Character Expansion
item.comment: A nice character with interesting abilities that provide a distinct falvour to the game. Although I expected a bit more content from an expansion.

item.name: Mage Knight Board Game: Shades of Tezla Expansion
item.comment: Not a bad expansion, although the component quality is lower than expected. Mechanics work well -especially the one-use items are great- but nothing too essential like the lost legion expansion. For this price I would like some more terrain features and action cards.

item.name: Mage Knight Board Game: The Lost Legion
item.comment: A great expansion, adds many extremely well integrated mechanics and content.

item.name: Mage Wars Arena
item.comment: Well, this the most anticipated game that let me down. Too much complexity that does not produce a robust feel in the game, like MtG does. Although I have to say I do not like summoner wars, and this is something like summoner wars + a whole lot of spells. I feel a bit confused. This game has everything I would expect in a game and still I didn't like it as much as I predicted.

item.name: Magic Realm
item.comment: Only one play, which didn't go well. I expected more narrative and more choices. Overall I enjoyed the feel of the game. I find mage knight superior in mechanics and in the overall feel.

item.name: Magic: The Gathering
item.comment: Excellent combo potential,replayability and card diversity.Strategy.Fantasy.Fun.AI coding almost impossible.But I would never pay so much for a pack of cards.

item.name: Magnum Sal
item.comment: Nothing new or fascinating but still a very enjoyable worker placement game with a very potent theme.

item.name: MagÂ·Blast (Third Edition)
item.comment: Nice. Fast. But the theme personally makes me wish for more complexity :)

item.name: Maharaja: The Game of Palace Building in India
item.comment: Many people find it better.I prefer other network games with more volatile income mechanisms.

item.name: Maka Bana
item.comment: Basic,light interaction game. The Tiki blocking mechanic is interesting (if you guess where your opponent is going, you block his action), however this is a game that's simpler than Tobago or Thurn and Taxis, so for an introductory/family game I'd recommend these two or Thebes or Stone Age who have substantial depth.

item.name: Mamma Mia!
item.comment: I think the designer of this game should design it a bit more.It feels like a weekend idea made into a game in Monday.There is some potential in the game though:see Souvlaki Wars

item.name: The Manhattan Project
item.comment: This is the definition of a euro-trash game. There is worker placement and specialization - which I very much liked, and there is also the ability to bombard your opponents, thus impeding their buildings. I saw many good mechanics but none great. I do not know why I didn't like the game more. I certainly did not like the end condition. Perhaps if it was a bit tighter - harder - it could limit my options and thus become more strategic. Anyhow, it's not a bad game.

item.name: Manila
item.comment: Nice gameplay.Very nice coins.

item.name: Manoeuvre
item.comment: I very much enjoyed the 5 hand size and the card use mechanic. It offers great strategic choices and styles of play.

item.name: Mansions of Madness
item.comment:
In comparison to "Betrayal at House on the Hill": Components: +++ Creative Writing/Stories: -- Korey is not a professional writer like Glassco, although this is only in comparison. The stories ARE good. Gameplay: ?+ about the same. Bit more strategic, particularly becase the bad guy plays a bit like Descent's overlord. But not the fulfilling strategic game we were expecting. Replayability: ?- Same, maybe a bit less.
If you do not own "Betrayal at House on the Hill" Buy it. It is a good family interactive story game with excellent components and good gameplay. You should own either this, or Betrayal, or Tales of the Arabian nights(more storytelling, less strategy)

item.name: Mare Nostrum
item.comment: I find that this game has a slightly similar feel to Cyclades.Is it a civ game?No.I needed effects and technological advancements to call it a civ.For me it is a respectable,robust,development/area control/set collection euro-trash. Exquisite board and illustrations.Maybe I need to have more plays to judge it properly.

item.name: Maria
item.comment: This is the wargame of choice if you like bluff tactics. Simple combat mechanic that works, and asymmetric powers. I have the feeling that bluff is the main strategy here. Must play again to judge.

item.name: Marrakech
item.comment: Too abstract for my taste, without the substantial depth of other abstract games.

item.name: Marvel Heroes
item.comment: Best quality of components I've seen.Best incorporation of theme in the strategy I've seen.(edit: 2nd to MEQ) However it easily takes a lot of modding with which it could bear vast improvements.

item.name: Masques
item.comment: Did not work for me, although it did seem promising from the rules. The "take that" element takes away most of the fun.

item.name: Master Thieves
item.comment: I would pay 20 euros for this not-so-much-fun but original memory game.It costs 90...

item.name: Medici
item.comment: Reference bidding game with simplest rules and some deeper strategies. Enjoyable,classic Knizia.

item.name: Memoir '44
item.comment: My first war game.A simple but efficient non-boring system for beginners at war games and board games in general.It is mature and as good as it could be.

item.name: Merchant of Venus (second edition)
item.comment: Excellent game! Complexity sweetspot, simple rules, non-boring trade, balanced and strategic upgrades, choices and technologies. Excellent reimplementation. The best trade/exploration and the best pick up and deliver game I've played, even though I tend to dislike pick up and deliver games.

item.name: Merchants & Marauders
item.comment: An excellent reference pirate-themed game. Personally I wish for a bit more complexity/depth/weight, however for a standard gamer the gameplay sits on the correct spot. Some glory points came too easily I think. There are lots of interesting mechanics and it does capture perfectly the feel of the era. I would recommend this as the reference pirates' game, although I must also try GMT's blackbeard.

item.name: Merkator
item.comment: Some common mechanics with uwe's previous 2 gems, like the harvest element and different resources with certain abilities. This is not a bad game, and it has some intereting balances while it lasts a lot less than agricla and le havre. It also requires much less explanation. It felt like Uwe was going for a distillation of his previous games but the result feels rather like a family eurogame than a deep game. Not a bad game overall. Excellent production.

item.name: Metro
item.comment: Oh my... why don't I try to rearrange my spaghetti,it would be more fun. Clashes with Cadwallon: city of thieves for the title of "worst game ever".

item.name: Metropolys
item.comment: Nice bidding euro-nothing too exciting though,with an innovative mechanism that can be a lot of fun with the right group.

item.name: Meuterer
item.comment: A great and compact game that could be better if the roles were more carefully created and the mutiny less frequent.Great value for money!

item.name: Middle Kingdom
item.comment:
Hey! this game is way underrated! much better than other similar Knizia-clones. I enjoyed it,it's fast and I like the different abilities.
After some plays I have to say I see even more depth than before.

item.name: Middle-Earth Quest
item.comment: This is an excellent game! I don't know how to classify it: the best I could say is that it's an accurate thematic representation of the events in middle earth as we know of them. The thematic incorporation in the mechanics is the best I've seen in a game. It also has excellent and balanced assymetrical play between Sauron and the heroes with innovative combat mechanics and other hidden secrets that provide ground for the Sauron player to be cunning and thus, provide a replayable challenge. You can feel the mechanics and strategies work in parallel with your intuition from the books or the movies, without comprosing the gameplay not even a bit. It is the best Ameritrash game I've played so far.

item.name: Might & Magic Heroes
item.comment: A very nicely worked game, seems the product of extensive playtests and hard work. I have to compare it to mage knight, although the mechanics are completely different. It is a lighter one, with much less explanation time. I did not like the brutal player interaction, nor the player area influence mechanic, I would like less territorial conflict between players or an official variant that supports it. It is a very nice transfer of the computer game and a game worthy to have in your collection. As I am writing this the game has a rank of 2000+ which must be a BGG algorithm fail. The game deserves at least top 300 rank.

item.name: Mille Bornes
item.comment: My first game other than monopoly...I have made a custom expansion with cars with special abilities

item.name: MindTrap
item.comment: A nice game that predates "black stories" and has many mathematical and deduction riddles and puzzles some of which are of great quality!

item.name: The Mines of Zavandor
item.comment: Nice resource management/bidding euro. Also, one of Klemens Franz's best works! I like the many different cards. The game doesn't last that long so abilities/vps importance is balanced, which I personally don't prefer, but that's irrelevant. I also would rather have the Clans in unlimited slots outside my board and I prefer a variant that gives me more control over my upgrades.

item.name: Mission: Red Planet
item.comment: An nice area influence game.The characters resemble those from citadles but are less interesting.Could be a lot of fun with the correct party.I think something better could be done with the area influence mechanism.

item.name: Modern Art
item.comment:
It has nice mechanics but particularly the round ending conditions I think needed a major tweak. They make the game feel very counter-intuitive. Also the way that you play your hand feels counter-intuitive.
I prefer "For Sale".

item.name: Mondo
item.comment: This is ultra light galaxy trucker phase 1 only. I had fun, but would not play again. There is nothing to draw me to the table for another play.

item.name: Monkey Lab
item.comment: It has a correct scoring mechanism, but the main gameplay is repetitive and simplistic. Nice components also.

item.name: Montgolfiere
item.comment: A nice funny filler with some bluffing and strategy.

item.name: Moral Dilemma
item.comment: Nice theme but the mechanics are too simplistic and many of the dilemmas seemed to need more work.

item.name: Mord im Arosa
item.comment: Innovative mechanic, of course. The strategy does exist a bit, but It could be a lot better to capture fully the potential of the new mechanic. We had some laughs, that's it. I am not sure if I'd play a 2nd time.

item.name: Mr. Jack
item.comment: Nice semi-abstract/semi-deduction 2 player game,move the right person to the right spot with a little bit of a mystery twist.

item.name: Munchkin
item.comment: Great artwork,but too simple mechanics for my taste.

item.name: Mundus Novus
item.comment: A nice trading game, with nice options between development abilities. The thematic resources are probably the best I've seen.

item.name: Municipium
item.comment: A reference worker placement-area influence game. Fast, and not pointless, with some good mechanics. Abstract games and interaction fans will like it. I am not a fan of those genres.

item.name: Mutant Meeples
item.comment: Ricochet robots v2.0, allows for more interaction, more brain burning, but apart from the robot abilities there are no new mechanics. Get it if you're into Ricochet robots puzzle game.

item.name: My Dwarves Fly
item.comment: A light fighting game with excellent artwork and many different abilities to enhance the many races who will fight for you. This game has potential. If it had a bit more advanced rules it could achieve even greater praises. Reminded me of Inn Fighting-although the gamepaly mechanics are different.

item.name: My Village
item.comment: I enjoyed it more than Village. There seem to exist many viable strategies and would like to play again soon.

item.name: Mykerinos
item.comment: Seems a pretty nice straightforward light euro. I love the interaction of the abilities vs the scoring conditions vs the strategic placement of cubes. Perhaps one of the few area influence games I would not avoid.

item.name: Mykerinos: The Nile
item.comment: Best feature is that it separates the board vertically. Other than that, nothing special.

item.name: The Mysteries of Peking
item.comment: Childhood! not a bad mystery game for children! :)

item.name: Mystery Express
item.comment: Somewhat similar to Mystery of the Abbey,however it misses on the atmoshpere,it does not have the clever questions you address to the other monks,no special events cards,and it is even more complicated in the whodunit part,as you search in 4 different categories instead of 1.Buy Mystery of the abbey instead,unless you have a thing for the movie Orient Express.

item.name: Mystery of the Abbey
item.comment: Very nice,thematic,fun party deduction game.I don't mind the complexity as it can be a lot of fun if played in a bit of rpg style.Nice looking board.Definetely the reference game for the whodunit genre.

item.name: Mystery of the Abbey with The Pilgrims' Chronicles
Mystery of the Abbey: The Pilgrims' Chronicles
Mystery Rummy: Jack the Ripper
item.comment: Perhaps I didn't get the game at the first play.

item.name: Myth: Pantheons
item.comment: It's actually not bad,although it resembles common trick taking games you could play with a deck of cards,although advanced and maybe more balanced.I should play again to form a better opinion,but that is not likely.

item.name: Mythotopia
item.comment: Well, no, it doesn't reimplement A few acres of snow. It feels like a hybrid between aFAoS and Antike. It plays well, although the area control element is too chaotic. I find it inferior than aFAoS, but still a game that I enjoyed. Something is missing to tie the mechanics together in the same way as other Wallace games.

item.name: The Name of the Rose
item.comment: It's like mystery of the abbey,more strategic though,but stripped of the excellent artwork and the fun.Can be good only with a specific party of strict eurostrategy fans.

item.name: Nations
item.comment: Through the ages lite. Not bad at all. I like the fact they stayed a mainstream course. The main strategy is "balance management", just like in through the ages. Apart from that, there are minor similarities in the mechanics. I expected more from the graphic design though. Especially the backgrounds seem a bit simplistic. Some tracks would be nice too. After some plays: the game has depth! for a clear 10 I would like something more innovative with the card offer.

item.name: Navegador
item.comment: An excellent game that felt like Wallace's design logic. It has weird economic balances and a weird feel (good weird). Tight and simple choices without being boring. Lots of nice mechanics - it is my first Gerdts game.

item.name: Nefarious
item.comment: A light inventions game with an evil-scheming theme I prefer. It could be better though, even for a light game. Perhaps some different invention effects were needed.

item.name: Nefertiti
item.comment: Nice strategy,but Ystari board colors.Always orange!come on you guys.

item.name: Nefertiti Expansion
item.comment: Nothing too fancy, a few extra mechanics which I am not sure that work excellently. If the game lasted longer the foreign gifts would work better. Also, not sure if you can lose them via character cards, in which case it's all a mess.

item.name: Neuland
item.comment: A resource production game. The manual is useless. I have played about 360 games at the time I am writing this. It is one of the worst manuals I've seen. I do not understand the time track, although I can deduct the way it should work. The strategy is peculiar because the progress you make in each round can be easily use by other players. I should have another play to rate accurately.

item.name: Neuroshima Hex!
item.comment: A "miniatures" close combat game that is not bad at all. Your tiles (units) have various abilities that affect the (very small) field of battle, which is constantly changing. That's one of the things I didn't like, I'd like a larger grid with some permanent elements on it. The tiles that provide abilities to adjacent units could be made to withstand more hits and the board could be larger. Having said that, if you don't mind that the game is on the verge of being characterized as abstract, you'll enjoy it.

item.name: Nexus Ops
item.comment: The BEST at its kind: light fighting at close hexes with a flavour of starcraft. Units have intuitive abilities. Gameplay is balanced and enjoyable. Gametime is optimal.

item.name: Niagara
item.comment: Too simple for me,yet ideal for non gamers that like simple games.It is kind of fun,but I would not buy it.For introductory games I'd prefer Tobago or Mystery of the abbey.

item.name: Nicht die Bohne!
item.comment: Didn't get it the first time. I don't see any reason for a 2nd time. :(

item.name: Nightfall
item.comment:
What I liked: * A typicial deck building game that does have some strategic originalities. * Two actual "periods" in the game: your initial hand is eventually out of the game. * Illustrations.
What I did not like: * Graphic design. * Overall gameplay (although I played with 5 and only once). * Theme. * Many cards have similar effects. * The abstract colored chain mechanic. It does work well balance-wise but it is too abstract to be incorporated in a thematic game. The colors could be substituted by factions or card types. I think that would give the game a great boost.

item.name: Ninjato
item.comment:
A nice action point allowance game. Reminds me of stone age in the way the resources are used. Has a bit of a trick taking element (player vs the game) in the way the are gathered. Did not like the fact that you can constantly mess with factions' vp after a succesful purge. That adds some really unnecessary brain burning to the game. I did like the scoring condition cards very much.
Overall I liked it.

item.name: No Thanks!
item.comment: Nice gameplay.Simple but not boring.

item.name: Norenberc
item.comment: Another great euro from Andreas. Simple mechanics but robust gameplay and interesting choices each turn. I have to say it puts furstenfeld out of the map.

item.name: Notre Dame
item.comment: Excellent strategic choices.Excellent game of medium complexity.I would pay more for better component quality.Plays well with all group sizes.

item.name: Nottingham
item.comment: It's an ok filler,couldn't grasp if there is more strategy to it from one play.

item.name: Nuns on the Run
item.comment: Although I do prefer more complex games, I thind this is the game of choice of its kind. I have also played fury of dracula, escape from the aliens in outer space, letters from whitechapel.

item.name: Oh My Goods!
item.comment: There is nothing wrong with this resource management game, but nothing exceptional either. At 2015, it is an ok game. A positive trait: cards are used 3 ways, like in race for the galaxy. A negative trait: the double card draw each round to determine the random resource offer is a bit tiresome.

item.name: Oh, Really!
item.comment: A nice "guess what the other person prefers" party game, in the genre of say anything and/or gifttrap. Although simplistic, this one might also provide grounds for some interesting discussions.

item.name: Olympos
item.comment: A nice area control with intense civ technologies flavour. It has many just rules regarding the takeover of territories and the careful balance between weighing a costful action and the time spent. I agree that it needed clearer graphics as resource icons.

item.name: Olympus
item.comment: A development game with a "take that" interaction. Works well, not great. If developed more it could be a hit of a game. PS HATE the gods illustrations and the color choices.

item.name: Ora et Labora
item.comment:
I am afraid the strategy resembles very much le havre. Mechanics borrow a lot from farmers of the moor and le havre. However it is a very good resource management game, but I cannot advise le havre owners to buy it.
Very good and beautiful game overall. If you like resource management, or if you liked Le Havre but hated its food requirements, this game is for you.

item.name: OrlÃ©ans
item.comment: An innovative take on the "worker building" mechanic, introduced in "Archon" by sot07. This is a full game experience with many different aspects, and it needs at least 2 plays to be able to grasp the strategy, as it is possible for some workers to become obsolete after some turns.

item.name: Othello
item.comment: Not bad.

item.name: PAC-MAN Game
item.comment: Childhood!

item.name: Pack & Stack
item.comment: Very nice artwork,but the gameplay has little to offer,unless you have some non gamer friends over.Although there are nicer games for that occasion...

item.name: Palazzo
item.comment: This time the Knizia recipe worked to provide a nice game.Of course it would be a great game if the building tiles had unique abilities,but then again R.Knizia is not Stefan Feld...

item.name: Palmyra
item.comment: This could be one of the few abstract tile placement games that I'd play twice. It is my worst genre, but I enjoyed my first play. I very much liked the fact that your vp goal per turn is also your vp bonus and you can optionally increase it turn by turn.

item.name: Pan T'es Mort
item.comment: A very nice, fast and clever trick taking/push your luck with a twist!

item.name: Pandemic
item.comment: I like the different roles.Simple but interesting family game.Nice theme incorporation.I'd like each city to have slightly different attributes.

item.name: Pandemic: On the Brink
item.comment: A typical expansion. Nothing too necessary, adds some new events/diversity. The extra roles are very useful.

item.name: Panic Station
item.comment: Not quite what I expected. Not as streamlined as I would like. It smells "indy" in a bad way: too fiddly with the back and forth movements, and the exploration/tile placing part is rather out of date, many rooms are the same. The infection mechanic/victory conditions work pretty well and I wasn't let down in that area.

item.name: Pantheon
item.comment: Excellent! this game along with Stone Age made me a fan of Mr. Brunnhofer. Paul Lister (sorp122) praised this game and he was correct. It is a family game but also a gamers game, a rare quality also found in Stone age. It is civ-themed which I love and it provides developing choices over an hour and a half. Almost perfect. I wished for a more robust design to rate it a perfect 10, but still! You did it again Mr Tummelhofer/Brunnhofer!

item.name: Panzer General: Allied Assault
item.comment: The first play was great! light rules, but very compact, with many good mechanics. Althrough replayability might be an issue, it's a good wargame.

item.name: Parthenon: Rise of the Aegean
item.comment:
Nice civ game with opportunistic development and exceptional illustrations,but the trade between players could be replaced with another mechanic. Also,I am not at all sure of its replayability value. Still a game I very much enjoyed.
meta-comment: I had the feeling of losing control towards the end of the game also in another Andrew Parks game, Core Worlds.

item.name: Pass the Bomb
item.comment: It's fun, although extra simple word game. There could be some more elements to spice it up a bit. I like the fact that the bomb's ticking time is random!

item.name: Pastiche
item.comment: One of the most "thematic" abstract games out there. It is fun to combine the various colours to get new ones but unfortunately the all-changing set collection goal in each round makes it just another abstract game with vague purpose.

item.name: Patchistory
item.comment: Another excellent civ game that fulfills its promises, with great art. The balances work well and the resources retain their different character very well. Preferably, use https://www.boardgamegeek.com/filepage/96778/capoeiristas-rules-rewrite

item.name: Patchwork
item.comment: Definition of elegant design - one of the few tile placement games I enjoyed, although it feels like the mechanic could be even better implemented in a non-abstract game.

item.name: Pathfinder Adventure Card Game: Rise of the Runelords â€“ Base Set
item.comment: A great RPG - adventure boardgame feel! Need more plays to judge the strategy. Love the fact that it is by default in campaign mode. Not as deep as Lord of the rings LCG, but still great, although it lacks proper wording.

item.name: Pathfinder Adventure Card Game: Rise of the Runelords â€“ Character Add-On Deck
item.comment: The new characters are very interesting but I think they are also downloadable. The cards are not something special, they mainly allow for 5-6 players games.

item.name: Pathfinder Adventure Card Game: Rise of the Runelords â€“ The Hook Mountain Massacre Adventure Deck 3
item.comment: Basic game gets even more strategic with the deck thinning mechanism after the introduction of the adventure, and I noticed some more elaborate mechanics.

item.name: Pathfinder Adventure Card Game: Rise of the Runelords â€“ The Skinsaw Murders Adventure Deck 2
item.comment: Expected more complex mechanics.

item.name: Patrician
item.comment: I don't see any obvious depth,and it's not that fun either.

item.name: Patronize
item.comment: Well, it has something to say among other trick taking games, but I can't say I got the feel of the game.

item.name: PAX
item.comment: Nice one! I wish it lasted longer though. I felt there was not enough time to take advantage of all the potential combos.

item.name: Pax Porfiriana
item.comment:
Ok. Hmmm. On one hand, you have to respect Phil Eklund and his pure originality of spirit. On another hand, he should respect the progress of the boardgame community. I think his games are brilliant but they require some SERIOUS streamlining. Hire a graphic designer, for starters.
I saw some great mechanics in this game. However, it still feels like it's in playtest phase: although it is quite balanced, there are elements that feel rough and exotic...in a bad sense. Phil's games are extremely hard to rate.
Excellent fluff, of course. Hated the simple "take that" interaction, but liked the compensation.

item.name: Pelican Cove
item.comment: Nice one! Funny, fast, and great as a drinking game!

item.name: Peloponnes
item.comment: Excellent minimalist civ game with a bidding mechanism.Delicious per-round production to be weighed against immediate bonuses and a lot of planning for a civ game that lasts less than 1 hour.The artwork is nice,however it could be better on the player mats and the tile backs.Check the alternate backs I've uploaded in the game's images,which take advantage of the starting cities' artwork and include a feeding warning for B and C tile backs.

item.name: Peloponnes Card Game
item.comment: It captures the feel of Peloponnes, however it lasts shorter and feels more of a "travel edition" than a card game. Rules are almost the same. No innovations since the original. Liked it less than the original.

item.name: Peloponnes Expansion
item.comment: It fills up a void by rewarding players who have gathered extra resources.

item.name: Peloponnes: Athens-Mini Expansion
item.comment: Not sure if it works that well. You do have to forfeit a round for 3 cash, so it is only useful if you know you won't be able to come through, and it takes up on of the 5 tiles. That means that with 5 players one of them will get a tile only every 2 rounds.

item.name: Peloponnes: Hellas Expansion
item.comment: I like the extra round and the extra tiles.

item.name: Pergamon
item.comment: Heavier than it seems. It lasts about 45 mins but it is a lot more strategic than it seems on the first play, or by reading the rules. It also contains a fresh "push your luck" interactive mechanic that works very very well. It is also a great production. Other games with small duration but deep strategies I can think of are Glen More and Notre Dame. This goes alongside with them.

item.name: Perikles
item.comment: One example of absolutely fine Wallace balance.Game designers should take notes here.But is the game enjoyable as brass?Not so.I loved the tile quality in this production.A must for all Wallace fans!

item.name: The Phantom League
item.comment: I can't pinpoint what I didn't like. Obviously it needed a bit more mainstreaming, rules trimming and less micromanagement. However, as it is inspired by the Elite PC game, less micromanagement could ruin the point of the game. I did like the innovative battle system. I liked every aspect of the game at least a bit, but there was no main aspect that I enjoyed greatly.

item.name: The Phantom League: Mostly Harmless
item.comment: Who needs more of everything in a game that is already too much?

item.name: Phantom League: Pilot Academy
item.comment: It improves the battle system.

item.name: Phoenicia
item.comment: A nice light, civ-themed development game that plays very fast. Excellent addition to the genre.

item.name: Pick-a-Dog
item.comment: Pretty funny game and replayable, despite the simple mechanic. Another good one in this motif is bobby sitter.

item.name: Pickomino
item.comment: One of the best fillers ever. A similar mechanic is applied in Yspahan, which is a fuller game.

item.name: Pico 2
item.comment: This is actually clever!!! pretty nice and simple. excellent actually for settling small arguments and such :)

item.name: The Pillars of the Earth
item.comment: The definition of what worker placement games should be like.Excellent variability of actions,lots of different events.With the expansion it gets even more diverse.

item.name: The Pillars of the Earth: Expansion Set
item.comment: Adds many useful components/actions,however does not add any major new elements.In my opinion it is a very good -and needed expansion.

item.name: Pinguin-Party
item.comment: Although it seems fast enough,I'm not sure how fun it is.Is there strategy in this game?don't get it.

item.name: Pirate's Cove
item.comment: A simple pirate game with a bit of development as I remember it. Not bad.

item.name: Piraten kapern
item.comment: A simple but nice push your luck game with dice.

item.name: Pirates of the Spanish Main: Shuffling the Deck
item.comment: A deduction card game with pirates, brilliant artwork and treasure. In the footsteps of Guillotine, only with even better artwork and a deduction element.

item.name: Pit
item.comment: Simplistic trading real time game, which could produce some laughs but almost zero strategy.

item.name: PitchCar
item.comment: A nice reference dexterity game. I keep thinking the walls could need a different material for extra stability and the track could use some more imagination, but still it is the dexterity of choice for a large group of people.

item.name: PitchCar Extension
item.comment: Adds some diversity needed for large tracks.

item.name: Planet Steam
item.comment: A robust economic / commodity speculation economic development game that imbues each of the 4 resources with unique character and provides conditions for an excellent market manipulation mechanic.

item.name: Pocket Civ
item.comment: A great solo civ game that deserves more recognition. It has the sweetspot between the military/civ aspect imo and it is a hard game where technologies really make or break your strategy. A must try for all fans of civ or solo games.

item.name: Polis: Fight for the Hegemony
item.comment: This is a great addition to the civ/area control genre. The game features simple rules and is beatiful in the eye. However it is deeper than it seems at a first glance and takes a long time to master. There are several strategies available to try. I do not find it a design flaw, but the game is harder than what I would like, that is why I will probably not play it as often. However my excellent rating stands.

item.name: Ponzi Scheme
item.comment: It certainly is an innovative economic game. The only remotely similar game I've played is crunch.

item.name: Popular Front
