item.comment: A very underrated light wargame that plays great with 6 players. the component quality is so-so but the game, if you have the correct group, game doesn not disappoint. Could be more assymetrical - thematic.

item.name: Port Royal
item.comment: A very promising game, although the victory condition needs some house rules.

item.name: Power Grid
item.comment: Hate the theme but what a balanced game!

item.name: Power Grid: BGG Promo Card Set
item.comment: Nice. Adds some interesting strategic choices without messing up the main game.

item.name: Power Grid: Factory Manager
item.comment: A decent game, although I cannot judge its depth. It has some common calculatory processes with power grid, but is a totally different game, it feels like one of Wallace's economic games.

item.name: Power Grid: The First Sparks
item.comment: I prefer this from power grid. Probably I am the only one, but I very much like the civ feel it gets, and I would even like it more if there were more "ability" cards! I also care for the new "bid" mechanic, take it or leave it. Great! faster. less calculative. Great artwork too.

item.name: Power Grid: The Stock Companies
item.comment: Although somewhat well designed, unfortunately I don't think this module fits this game.

item.name: Praetor
item.comment: Nice worker placement game, I would prefer it without the spatial element though, and perhaps if it lasted a bit longer.

item.name: The Princes of Florence
item.comment: This is a pretty nice bidding game with some interesting balances. However, I dislike the spatial element, and I think it does not deserve such high rank.

item.name: The Princes of Machu Picchu
item.comment: An economic/resource management game. In comparison with other Gerdts games I was not satisfied. Overall though it is a nice game. Yes, I do wish for a less random delivery of the scoring mechanism although as a scoring mechanic it is balanced. It could be the first artwork I see that uses live pictures next to sketches, and doesn't look that bad.

item.name: Princes of the Renaissance
item.comment: Weird wallace balance.But still nice.

item.name: Principato
item.comment: A light economic game but with substantial depth and nice balances. The 2nd game from Touko that I like! I compare it to St Petersburg.

item.name: Il Principe
item.comment: Many different mechanics (drafting, area control, role picking) , tied well together. However I did not see any innovations, so I would only recommend this game to gamers who have not seen many area control eurogames.

item.name: Progress: Evolution of Technology
item.comment: It has very good potential but seems too loose. I think the mechanic of variant buy potential for each card is excessive. I would also like the game to be more tight, I felt I had too many easy options and could not decide my strategy. Other than that, it was enjoyable and gave a sense of development.

item.name: Project: ELITE
item.comment: Playtester comment: Very innovative fusion game, combines real time dice rolling with clever action planning, since you are not only weighing your dexterity against time but each of your actions has potential benefits for the alien invasion. My only remark was to limit the tactical micromanagement for the alien horde. The game is satisfying and strategic! good mechanics are in abundance. recommended.

item.name: Prophecy
item.comment: Vlaada made a masterfully balanced adventure game, which could very well be a disguised resource management-development game. Quality of components is top notch, but although playful and robust the artwork does not reach the standards of fantasy flight games. Combat mechanics are not better than runebound, but the overall balance and gameplay are quite better. Individual cards and events contribute greatly to the game's design.

item.name: Prophecy: Dragon Realm
item.comment: Another dimension added, coop scenario with many new skills added, and a lot of equipment. Nice pack for the best light adventure game out there.

item.name: Puerto Rico
item.comment:
Very good eurogame, with depth, strategy and diversity. However in comparison to better games, I do not still understand why it should be on the top 20. The mechanics were excellent for its time, but the overall game feels a bit weird. Particularly, I do not like the tile building restriction, and I do not like the kingmaking ability of the captain. Waiting for more plays to form a certain opinion.
edit: exceptionally strategic after more plays. Wish it was shifted on the development side though. A great eurogame.

item.name: Puerto Rico: Limited Anniversary Edition
item.comment: Component review: tiles: great! player mats/board: check! expansions: great! coins: meh. should be thicker/bigger, it's not easy to pick them up. box: pass. should be sturdier, but, great design.

item.name: Puzzle Strike
item.comment: I agree with Piscatella's comment: "this is what dominion should be like". I would also consider it as dominion for ameritrashers. A good game. Also, using chits instead of cards makes things easier physically.

item.name: Die Pyramiden des Jaguar
item.comment: I found a unique and weird strategy in the game, the way it handles number sequences. Its rating depicts the fun I had while playing.

item.name: Qin
item.comment: Although I normally dislike abstract games as a genre, this one was quite easy, meaningful and fun.

item.name: Quarriors!
item.comment: A different "deck" building game with interaction and conflict. Although I dislike immediate conflict in these games, this game I particularly liked. The great artwork and fantasy theme helped a lot. I'm guessing even deeper mechanics could be implemented, but so far I'm enjoying it much.

item.name: Quarriors! Rise of the Demons
item.comment: Needed expansion. Expands the strategic possibilities and choices by introducing "bad" dice.

item.name: Queen's Ransom
item.comment: A simple deduction game with some minor twists. Nothing special but it isn't too disappointing either.

item.name: Quoridor
item.comment: Nothing special.

item.name: Qwixx
item.comment: A nice push-your-luck / racing filler with interaction.

item.name: Ra
item.comment: The basis of comparison for all bidding games. A robust game. I can believe that there will be others, more interesting bidding games. But still, it is a complete design with depth and replayability.

item.name: Ra: The Dice Game
item.comment: A very nice short game that holds the scoring mechanics of Ra minus the auction + dice rolling / press your luck.

item.name: Race for the Galaxy
item.comment: Simply magnificient! The best card game there is out there. I can't say enough. The professionalism of the designer creates depth and a sense of fulfilment. Downtime is minimal and very well handled. Many different viable strategies. This is the 2nd best game I've played after through the ages, among 800+ different boardgames. The artwork and the fluff titles also contribute vastly to the feel of the game. Excellent overall.

item.name: Race for the Galaxy: Alien Artifacts
item.comment: The new cards are excellent and very intuitive! I am not sure I enjoyed the tile placement orb game though. Certainly the explore action is boosted up substantially, and this shifts the game's strategy. However the tile placement headache seems chaotic enough to trim a big portion of the enjoyment. I expected a longer game with different end conditions from this arc, but got a fiddly tile placement mini game instead.

item.name: Race for the Galaxy: Rebel vs Imperium
item.comment: Excellent balance from Tom Lehmann, but I wanted more cards for that price. Although RFTG is the #2 best game I've played so I'd blind buy any expansion that came along.

item.name: Race for the Galaxy: The Brink of War
Race for the Galaxy: The Gathering Storm
item.comment: I wanted more cards for that price. Although RFTG is the #2 best game I've played so I'd blind buy any expansion that came along.

item.name: Race for the Galaxy: Xeno Invasion
item.comment: The semi-coop mechanic works well. Other than that, I am still hoping for an expansion that will make the game longer without making it fiddlier, perhaps by extending the endgame conditions.

item.name: Rage
item.comment: Underrated trick taking clone game!

item.name: Railroad Barons
item.comment: Cutthroat economic game. You need the updated comprehensive manual. Not bad, but I'd rather play chicago express.

item.name: Rallyman
item.comment: The mechanic works and is enjoyable, but in 2015 I am hoping for something a lot more sophisticated than say snowtails, to be enthusiastic.

item.name: Rat-a-Tat Cat
item.comment: Fast, extra-simple and a bit fun.

item.name: Rattus
item.comment: A nice light euro.

item.name: The Red Dragon Inn
item.comment: I think it's one of the best in its genre, although I can't seem to pinpoint exactly why. Usually I don't like these light thematic party games.

item.name: Red November
item.comment: It's ok if you're into coop games,but nothing special.Very funny gnomes though :)

item.name: Red7
item.comment: Didn't grasp it at first play, but seems an innovative thrust to the trick taking genre.

item.name: Reef Encounter
item.comment: Deep abstract game,lots of hidden strategies to discover,although I was disappointed because the game does not boost the playing experience either by better artwork,or by a less confusing final scoring mechanism.

item.name: Reiner Knizia's Decathlon
item.comment: A reference push your luck game. I like it, but it should be more complex with more choices.

item.name: Relikt
item.comment: No point in playing this very beautifully illustrated game. There is no long term strategy. No short term strategy either.

item.name: The Republic of Rome
item.comment: A political simulation that relies on the players' understanding of balances to be a good game.It provides a dynamic system of threats and opportunities on which the players compete but also cooperate.It could still be a better game though.Rules are not that hard to comprehend as many people think.Theme is exactly the same as Hannibal:Rome vs Carthage.

item.name: The Resistance
item.comment: It's like werewolf, only different, in a way that it stands out for itself. Each round a leader decides a subset of players and a vote is held between them. Had a lot of fun when I played it. Could be even more developed though.

item.name: The Resistance: Avalon
item.comment: A rethemed resistance with some extra roles! very nice.

item.name: Revolution!
item.comment: A very light bidding -area control game, that could be a lot better with minor changes. The game looks superficial. Although there is a climax at about the half of the session, the beginning and the end did not satisfy me.

item.name: Rex: Final Days of an Empire
item.comment: Dune streamlined. Excellent 1979 mechanics, still fresh! Light wargame of choice for increased number of players. Thematically sound. A nice addition to your light wargames collection. Wish the manual included some kind of story.

item.name: Rialto
item.comment: A classic Feld game, which involves guessing other players' choices. Not a bad game, not one of his best.

item.name: Ricochet Robots
item.comment: As a puzzle game it's potent. But there is no twist, it's just a repetitive puzzle game.

item.name: Rio de la Plata
item.comment: I like the artwork! nice little tiles. A worker placement city-building game that feels independent mechanics-wise, not bad, although I have to see the war mechanism again to judge precisely.

item.name: Rise of Empires
item.comment: A resource management / area control light civ game, that reminds me a bit of mare nostrum and struggle of empires. Very balanced and robust but as with all area control games the interaction and the kingmaking didn't let me enjoy this game to its full potential.

item.name: Risk
item.comment: Simplistic. There are dozens of better area control games out there.

item.name: The Rivals for Catan
item.comment: Excellent 2p game that captures all of the magic of its predecessor (catan card game) with extremely good Menzel artwork. Do not play the introductory scenario. Go directly to era of gold.

item.name: River Dragons
item.comment: A light simultaneous action selection interaction game with the mechanic of anasazi.

item.name: Roads & Boats
item.comment: Nice development game,but maps with less interaction is a must!it gets messy when someone reaches a stone factory that you built near your base.

item.name: Robber Knights
item.comment: For an abstract game it's not that original,and it's too simple for my taste.The nice artwork in the box is really misleading as to the contents.

item.name: Robinson Crusoe: Adventures on the Cursed Island
item.comment:
Thank you.
Even before I judge the depth of this game after more plays, I can see that it will (hopefully) initiate a whole new genre of adventure games. Great!

item.name: Robinson Crusoe: Adventures on the Cursed Island â€“ Voyage of the Beagle (Vol. 1)
item.comment: An excellent and thematic campaign idea. I wanted just a bit stronger connection between the scenarios to call it perfect.

item.name: RÃ–K
item.comment: A reference, simple observation/reaction game.

item.name: Roll for the Galaxy
item.comment: A very nice game, has the feel of race for the galaxy and with some different dice mechanics the result is a bit longer game with very different strategies. Since race is a game that is meant to last 30 min, I would prefer that roll would be a game that lasted 2hrs. Anyhow, I think it is worth owning both games, independently of how you like rftg.

item.name: Roll for the Galaxy: Ambition
item.comment: I would like it to contain more tiles other than the starting ones for increased variety/replayability. Goals are not my favourite module in RFTG either. However, the new starting worlds provide a better experience than the vanilla game. Eager for another expansion.

item.name: Roll Through the Ages: The Bronze Age
item.comment: My definition of light civ. But why share a name? Anyhow,very nice development game,I compare it to Uruk.

item.name: Roll Through the Ages: The Iron Age
item.comment: As good as the late bronze age expansion. Similar mechanics, some similar strategies. It is worth having though even if you own late bronze age.

item.name: Roll Through the Ages: The Late Bronze Age
item.comment: Excellent expansion, the default way to play roll through the ages for me.

item.name: Rolling Japan
item.comment: An excellent surprise, love the mechanic.

item.name: Roma
item.comment: An interesting and fast duel game, although it is one of Feld's early creations, so it does not reach the level of his latest giants. However I did enjoy it, not sure about the replayability though.

item.name: Room 25
item.comment: A light coop tile game. Tries to be thematic but I did not really feel it in the mechanics. It's an ok game, but I would have to be convinced to have a second play. Perhaps the traitor variant would be more interesting.

item.name: Rory's Story Cubes
item.comment: A good idea. It could have great mechanics. It has no mechanics or, I was not convinced. Shame. Pretty useable if you can invent your own rules.

item.name: Royal Palace
item.comment: Great game,incorporates all succesful mechanics in a very robust and fulfilling gameplay.Bravo!

item.name: Rum & Pirates
item.comment: A family game, somewhat random, with opportunistic gameplay. Early Feld, not at his current level, though for a simple family game it was somewhat fun.

item.name: Rune Age
item.comment: A very nice addition to the deck building family. I don't mind that there are only 3 types of common cards to buy. I like the limited choices. I like the game. Great artwork too and at last! linen paper cards in a deck building game! More scenarios would be needed.

item.name: Runebound (Second Edition)
item.comment:
An adventure game I enjoy much, although it is in dire need of many official/unofficial modifications.
It is of course with some mechanics/cards from the expansions. The item costs are unbalanced. The red challenges could be more complex but the adventure variants address that issue well. It has one of the best combat systems that provides many strategic choices and interacts very good with the equipment. I also like the great illustrations and the fluff of the story (Vorakesh.. Margath.. those bastards! :D )
Since it provides a complete adventure experience I consider this the reference adventure game to which all others are measured as better or worse.
The house rules I apply:
1)progressive level up experience: First 2 levels cost 2 xp, then the cost increases by one. 2,2,3,4,5,6...
2)something to compensate for bad movement rolls: Setup: each player receives a random ritual with cost 4 or lower from the rituals and runes expansion. Each 3 movement dice may be spent (even after rolling) to remove one fatigue.
3)categorize the market deck to 4 decks: armor, weapons, miscelanneous and allies. The hero may choose which deck to draw from.

item.name: Runebound Essential Collection
item.comment: A lot of needed stuff to increase replayability in a good price.

item.name: Runebound: Battlemage Character Deck
item.comment:
Not quite what I expected, as I guessed that all 30 cards would be Talent cards. Instead there are 5 Talent (level-up) cards and 25 once off cards.
As a deck building variant, or a draft variant it is a lot better though. It offers interaction and more strategy. But one has got to know the characters well.

item.name: Runebound: Beasts and Bandits
item.comment: A bounty on beastflesh is the best card here, I think. It also addresses the issue of bad movement rolls. An ok expansion overall.

item.name: Runebound: Blade Dancer Character Deck
item.comment:
Not quite what I expected, as I guessed that all 30 cards would be Talent cards. Instead there are 5 Talent (level-up) cards and 25 once off cards.
As a deck building variant, or a draft variant it is a lot better though. It offers interaction and more strategy. But one has got to know the characters well.

item.name: Runebound: Champions of Kellos
item.comment: I didn't really see any new mechanics in here, though the cards are ok.

item.name: Runebound: Crown of the Elder Kings
item.comment: A nice adventure not far away from the basic one. The green guardians' reward works better with many players.

item.name: Runebound: Relics of Legend
item.comment: Some very good "build up" mechanics here.

item.name: Runebound: Rituals and Runes
item.comment: Probably the most essential expansion, since it addresses the problem of the useless movement dice. I always play a variant that gives each player a random ritual on the setup of the game.

item.name: Runebound: Runemaster Character Deck
item.comment:
Not quite what I expected, as I guessed that all 30 cards would be Talent cards. Instead there are 5 Talent (level-up) cards and 25 once off cards.
As a deck building variant, or a draft variant it is a lot better though. It offers interaction and more strategy. But one has got to know the characters well.

item.name: Runebound: Shadow Walker Character Deck
item.comment:
Not quite what I expected, as I guessed that all 30 cards would be Talent cards. Instead there are 5 Talent (level-up) cards and 25 once off cards.
As a deck building variant, or a draft variant it is a lot better though. It offers interaction and more strategy. But one has got to know the characters well.

item.name: Runebound: Spiritbound Character Deck
item.comment:
Not quite what I expected, as I guessed that all 30 cards would be Talent cards. Instead there are 5 Talent (level-up) cards and 25 once off cards.
As a deck building variant, or a draft variant it is a lot better though. It offers interaction and more strategy. But one has got to know the characters well.

item.name: Runebound: The Cataclysm
item.comment: Another nice adventure with the added element of nomadic markets, which really compensates the worthless movement dice issue. Pretty hard bosses here. Nice.

item.name: Runebound: The Dark Forest
item.comment: A nice expansion with nice mechanics on the cards, but not essential.

item.name: Runebound: The Scepter of Kyros
item.comment: Probably on of the best adventure variants. It lets the bad guys build up and use items, while the heroes need to limit their visits to towns, as with every visit the end game gets harder. Nice.

item.name: Runebound: The Seven Scions
item.comment: Excellent adventure variant! sheds some focus on some neglected skill checks, and provides a good challenge! Try it!

item.name: Runebound: Traps and Terrors
item.comment: A very nice addition! probably the most difficult, sinister and interesting challenges! another must have.

item.name: Runebound: Weapons of Legend
item.comment: An ok expansion with some nice new cards.

item.name: Runebound: Wildlander Character Deck
item.comment:
Not quite what I expected, as I guessed that all 30 cards would be Talent cards. Instead there are 5 Talent (level-up) cards and 25 once off cards.
As a deck building variant, or a draft variant it is a lot better though. It offers interaction and more strategy. But one has got to know the characters well.
My favourite character deck!

item.name: Runewars
item.comment: Lots of different things to do and the game with heroes feels parallel to the main game. I couldn't help feeling a bit commercial about the game: I am not so sure how well all those mechanics tie in together. The modular board is beautiful, the combat mechanics work well. I would also prefer to gain immediately resources from conquered areas and then my opponent should force me to lose income by playing the Harvest action if my income does not correspond to my areas. Lots of other ideas about the game exist, but this is one of the epic games of choice.

item.name: Russian Railroads
item.comment: Excellent development euro over some predefined strategies that intermix very well. What CO2 should be. Wish it lasted a tad longer. Very well balanced. Respect!

item.name: Saboteur
item.comment: An ok filler with nice flow.The scoring mechanism could be better without increasing the difficulty of the game.

item.name: Saint Petersburg
item.comment: A very good economic game, in comparison with Tummelhofer's other 2 games which are family-development games. I wanted more diversity in the roles so the game was not clearly economic and not just about the balance between the Vp and the money. Anyhow, a very pleasant game overall.

item.name: Saint Petersburg (second edition)
item.comment: At least as good as the original, which I have rated a 10. Some card balance issues are succesfully addressed by the extra phase, however I am not certain that it doesn't burden the game.

item.name: Saint Petersburg: New Society & Banquet Expansion
item.comment: Î‘dds more diversity and useful cards. You should get it if you like the base game.

item.name: Saint Petersburg: The Banquet
item.comment: Nothing too essential.

item.name: San Juan
item.comment: The family version of Race for the Galaxy. I don't know if and who ripped off whom, however both games are brilliant. I prefer RFTG for the theme, the artwork, and the expansions. I'd like to see some increased variability expansions for San Juan also. However if you are confused by the depictions on RFTG and are seeking a simpler card game that feels like RFTG and is Puerto rico-themed, try this.

item.name: Santa Cruz
item.comment: An enjoyable eurogame of medium complexity and another excellent menzel work.

item.name: Santiago de Cuba
item.comment: A nice euro, using the artwork and some mechanics from cuba, and a "rondel"-like mechanic. The spatial element of Cuba is missing, which I think is for the best.

item.name: Die SÃ¤ulen der Erde: das Kartenspiel
item.comment: Game is not bad at all, considering I don't like trick taking games. Can be played by non-German speakers easily.

item.name: Saustall
item.comment: Too simplistic when compared with other "creative deduction" games. I am not talking of course about Android which is way too complicated, but about Tobago for instance, which is a much better game. There is some light strategy for your first game perhaps. After that, avoid this.

item.name: Say Anything
item.comment: Very nice idea,but the questions could be a lot better,only a few of them are really intriguing.Shame.But still a nice party game that thrives in certain groups!

item.name: Scarab Lords
item.comment: Not so bad! the card quality/artwork is very good and the gameplay it self is a pretty robust duel. Of course it lies on the thin line between collectible and standalone card game, but I liked my first plays. Not sure if one gets bored of the cards though.

item.name: The Scepter of Zavandor
item.comment: Excellent! although a bit prone to AP, we needed another light economic game like this! The game offers many delicious developing choices each turn: more immediate income, the foundations for future income, the lift of some restrictions, the advancement on "technologies", the acquisition of abilities or scoring conditions...it's great! and it also comes with a nice theme. Will play again many times!

item.name: Schinderhannes
item.comment: The board is not bad,the historical details in the manual are not bad,but Tobago is a much better game in the constructive deduction genre.

item.name: Scrabble
item.comment: A reference word game. I don't find it that boring but since it was one of my few overplayed childhood games I prefer to play something else.

item.name: Seasons
item.comment: A 7 wonders - with a wiz war spell feel - alternative. If the card effects were even more balanced it would be a great game. Looking forward to more plays to judge.

item.name: Seasons: Enchanted Kingdom
item.comment: Interesting expansion, abilities are good but not innovative, they resemble the extra actions, while the cards offer more diversity and combos.

item.name: Sentinels of the Multiverse
item.comment: A very nice first play, with great colourful comic-style illustrations. This kind of games though, should be judged on replayability, of which I am not convinced. Have to play again. 2nd play- I have the same disappointment as in my first play: I find it difficult for all players to keep track of what all the active villain cards do and which they should target. It comes down to the responsibility of a "narrator" player to continuously point out and clarify the situation. I sincerely think a more centralized mechanic (perhaps a synthesis of the various villain abilities to a board with some tracks) would greatly help.

item.name: SET
item.comment: Very nice idea that supports a whole game! Probably the reference quick observation game for me.

item.name: Seven of Seven
item.comment: Probably the most atmospheric metaphysical filler out there!Although gameplay seems to have room for maturing,it has a lot of potential.Definetely worth a bit more effort.I need more plays to speak about the strategy.Thematically,one of Cimino's signature games.The number 7 is present throughout the game in a terrifying streak of coincidences-or clever design?

item.name: Shadow Hunters
item.comment: Another hidden role game, like kutschfahrt,lupus in tabula etc. Some fresh mechanics which work. If you're a fan of hidden role games, it will work for you. It worked for me - nothing too exciting though.

item.name: Shadowrun: Crossfire
item.comment: First few games were extremely hard to beat. Can't yet figure out what went wrong.

item.name: Shadows over Camelot
item.comment: I enjoy it very much. It is a beautiful production with brilliant artwork, and among the few family coops of choice that I can also enjoy with my gamer friends.

item.name: Shadows over Camelot: Merlin's Company
item.comment: Diversity and some increased difficulty due to the movement restrictions. Nothing too exciting.

item.name: Shadows over Camelot: The Card Game
item.comment: A pretty nice little game with a memory mechanic that works well. You do have to coop. And the traitor role provides a joyful twist.

item.name: Shadows over the Empire
item.comment: A very well playtested area influence game with carefully chosen abilities, which is the main aspect of this game and makes it shine. For the artwork: excellent illustration skills. I would like the informational icons to stand out more though. They blend in the colours of the illustration a bit too much.

item.name: Sherlock Holmes Consulting Detective
item.comment:
Very alternative way of thinking. Got to have the right group to play. This game is a genre itself, an excellent addition to boardgames.
After some plays, I have to say, the game plays A LOT better if you master your first case. It should have a walkthrough and a sample story I think.
Also, some stories, e.g. story 7 (Banker's Quietus) seem almost impossible to solve completely and there is no explanation of how Holmes walked through some of the deductive steps. This is the only fault of the game.

item.name: Shipyard
item.comment: A galaxy trucker more euro style.A potent game,I did like it although it could be a bit less calculative.There is some AP.The money chits are ridiculously small,definetely use some from another game.The artwork is bearable.

item.name: Shogun
item.comment: One thing I don't like in area control games,that a bad player can ruin the game for a good one.However with balanced and strategic action selection mechanics,this is the next generation of the area control games.Even eurofans like Vagos adore it.

item.name: Sid Meier's Civilization: The Board Game
item.comment: Resembles the computer game a lot. WOW factor is max. The battle system is actually one of the strong elements in the game. My expectations for a pure 10 were not met, since I did not enjoy excellence in the pure civ aspect -the game is a bit more ameritrash than I'd like. Military conflict plays an important role and player interaction is more fierce than I would like. Resources are very scarce. I'd like to see a cuba-like mechanism that transforms resources into vps but there isn't any-well, there are some but you have to sacrifice your action to collect a resource. That's my greatest disappointment. Another one is that lots of the technologies -at least half I think- are aimed towards military confict and not civ development. One should try to keep a defense army and attack at the correct moment when he needs the benefits most. Wish it was more of a civ and less of an Ameritrash. Still it is a game I compare to and enjoy more than Twilight Imperium, which means: excellent work Kevin!

item.name: Sid Meier's Civilization: The Boardgame
item.comment: Huge epic game if you don't mind the micromanagement and the long hours. Covers many aspects of the computer game.

item.name: Singapore
item.comment: A fair try, but the end result is a game that has nothing more to offer than others in each kind, and also the whole "move your guy through the streets" thing is frustrating. Yes, it offers some strategy by limiting the options but the whole board is a mess after a while, so, I didn't like it.

item.name: Singapore: Essen 2011 bonus tiles
item.comment: Just simple interaction buildings. Alternative in a bad way.

item.name: Sitting Ducks Deluxe
item.comment: Funny but no replayability. Pretty pointless.

item.name: Skull
item.comment: One of the best, simple light and fast bluff games. Works lovely!

item.name: Slavika
item.comment: Did not like it. Random interaction ruins the game. Although the abilities seem interesting, it needed more rules to limit them.

item.name: Sleuth
item.comment: The basis for deduction games,ahead of its time,and it is also fun and quite replayable for its simplicity.The notepad could be a lot better designed.Don't like the artwork either,it is confusing and the colors don't provide a nice result.

item.name: Small World
item.comment: Nice,quick,not boring.Something is missing though...perhaps a few special effects cards,or a resource gathering mechanism?but then it wouldn't be so simple and quick.Oh well.

item.name: Smash Up
item.comment: I can't say I am satisfied. You cannot modify your deck throughout the game, although this does offer a quick setup and gameplay. One of the less interesting games of its kind.

item.name: SmileyFace
item.comment: This must be Faidutti's worst game. No strategy at all, too opportunistic. Very nice artwork!

item.name: Sneaks & Snitches
item.comment: I'll try to forget that Vlaada made this game. Although it seems promising, it's kind of random and too simplistic in the bad way.

item.name: Snorta!
item.comment: Har har. Nice for once in a 6 months or so...

item.name: Snow Tails
item.comment: Excellent theme incorporation.Fun game,although too simple.It would be over 9 for me,if you could gather upgrades during passing,like Jamaica.

item.name: Snowdonia
item.comment: A typical euro. Not bad at all, but can't see something sparkling either. There are some ways to get optimize the cards' effects, but other than that I didn't see a great strategy. It's fun enough to play though. Perhaps if there were abilities that interact more with eachother, the game would be a hit.

item.name: Sobek
item.comment: A very nicely illustrated filler that has nice gameplay. Resembles some classic set collection simple card games that you can play with a deck of cards, plus it offers some very nice extra effects. Recommended for non-gamer groups of simple card games fans.

item.name: Solitaire
item.comment: Not a bad abstract game. Although not too deep, it's a bit fun.

item.name: Souvlaki Wars
item.comment: A light serve-the-customers filler, with asymmetric but balanced player setup. bravo Vaggelis and congratulations for winning the GreekGuild's Boardgame Design Award for Best Game 2009! ps:I have heard that the graphic designer is a really weird person.

item.name: Space Alert
item.comment: If one card gets misplaced,all subsequent orders have random effects and there is no way to prevent this.Also,a lot of shouting during the planning phase decreases the game experience for me.But still,it is a very nice game to play

item.name: Space Cadets: Away Missions
item.comment: It is a tight tactics game (I dislike the genre) which works ok but at least in the first scenario I didn't find anything exciting.

item.name: Space Cadets: Dice Duel
item.comment: All ideas are good, but I think the white dice mechanic should be tighter. Overall I did not enjoy the realtime element as much, although the game looks like it could produce a lot of laughs in certain situations.

item.name: Space Hulk (third edition)
item.comment: Luxurious components,distilled satisfying gameplay,although for this price I would expect something even more sophisticated rules-wise and gameplay-wise.Although different genre,Marvel Heroes has similarly good components and gameplay,and is sold at 1/3 of the price.

item.name: Space Hulk: Death Angel â€“ The Card Game
item.comment: The game succeeds in its goal: a simple fast paced encounter in space warhammer40k-themed. Mechanics work well. For perfection, I wished for some more complexity though. Particularly the monster cards have virtually no info on them. They could have some abilities, even simple ones. Also a 1-2 more types of dice and mechanics to go with them would really bring the game close to a perfect 10.

item.name: Space Hulk: Death Angel â€“ The Card Game â€“ Mission Pack 1
item.comment: These 2 expansions offer a bit more complexity and variety to boost gameplay even further.

item.name: Space Hulk: Death Angel â€“ The Card Game: Space Marine Pack 1
item.comment: These 2 expansions offer a bit more complexity and variety to boost gameplay even further.

item.name: Spearpoint 1943
item.comment: Like "battle for hill 218", a light units filler wargame, that bets on correct calculation of variant useable firepower. There are a few tactics as well.

item.name: The Speicherstadt
item.comment: Nice one.Fresh bidding mechanic,and a working combination of draft/bidding.Terrible board art. The fresh mechanic, although brilliant in its conception, needed a bit more fine tuning. It really is a game in which you will make terrible mistakes at the first play.

item.name: Splendor
item.comment: A reference development game where you pick between future development and immediate goals. I would like some more depth, although the mechanics work well as is.

item.name: Spot it!
item.comment: I prefer it from jungle speed!

item.name: Star Realms
item.comment: Another good deck building game worth existing, but I still prefer Ascension.

item.name: Star Trek: Customizable Card Game (first edition)
item.comment: Well...it seems like an ok game that needed further development to be more streamlined. The foundation does support possibilities for various strategies but it lacks discipline in the rules and the mechanics I think, and the main set collection mechanic to achieve goals should be more lenient. Overall, not as professionally designed as other CCG's I'm afraid.

item.name: Star Trek: Expeditions
item.comment: Well, it is not as bad as expected. In fact, it is an astonishing production (apart from the 3 dice which are pathetic). The gameplay might also offer some replayability, and the game itself offers interesting choices. It does not remind me of another game. If you are a star trek fan you have a stronger motive to pay attention to your score, apart from trying not to lose. The game is good. It works. It offers different challenges each time, considering the initial setup. My first play left me with a complete feeling of star trek and a good game. I would like to be able to offer more on replayability but unfortunately I don't own the game.

item.name: Star Trek: Expeditions â€“ Expansion Set
item.comment: 3 nice characters as additions. Expected more content though.

item.name: Star Trek: Fleet Captains
item.comment:
Components: YES on the 2nd print run, FAIL on the first. The term "tiles" is a LIE. They are hexagonal CARDS. The clix miniatures and mechanic work great in the game! Cards are plastic but could easily become worn.
Gameplay: YES, clix are great, overall gameplay could be even better (see below)
Exploration: YES
Combat: Mehhh YES
Missions: Mehhh
Development: FAIL. Apart from assigning crew members there is no long term thinking here,only long term tactical strategies. Building defenses for example, could be a nice touch for longer games.
Cards: YES!
Game Setup: YES! excellent mechanics in the game setup, except from the spaceship "drafting", which is actually random.
Theme: Sure.

item.name: StarCraft: The Board Game
item.comment: 100% accurate capture of the computer game strategy and feel!kudos to corey for that.Now,reason it does not get above a 9,is that it felt a bit tight in the gameplay,and I am not sure about the replayability either.Exactly like the computer game :) For its price,I would choose another FF game of the same format,except if one is a fan of the computer game.Perfect capture.Not a bad game at all.

item.name: Start Player
item.comment: Some nice ideas but nothing too interesting.

item.name: The Staufer Dynasty
item.comment: An excellent short euro.

item.name: Steam
item.comment: An intuitive network train game with robust gameplay. Recommended to all network building fans.

item.name: Steampunk Rally
item.comment: It is a very nice mechanic, although I think a bit more limitations were needed and also the overwhelming kickstarter content actually hurt the game. Another thing is that this engine building mechanic would fit better in another theme, like a light civ perhaps. Building my vehicle while racing didn't feel quite intuitional.

item.name: Steel Driver
item.comment: Another extremely well balanced game from Wallace. The balances here are well hidden. There is no runaway leader, and no apparent viable strategy. The rules are extra simple but the struggle is tough. As with other Wallace games, the dividend payout in the endgame is unique.

item.name: Stellar Conflict
item.comment: A fast filler with a delicious resolve and funny strategies to explore.

item.name: Stephensons Rocket
item.comment:
I won't disagree that it is one of Knizia's good tries. For its time it should have been a top game. It is balanced and it does not suffer from pointless back and forth takeovers.
However in this genre there exist nowadays similar but better games, like Chicago Express(stock holding), or Steam (network building) that make this game obsolete.

item.name: Stone Age
item.comment: Congratulations to the designer M.Tummelhofer/B.Brunnhofer.One of my top 5 games.Excellent gameplay,one of Menzel's most magnificient boards,even non gamers try it,which is a miracle.Nothing more to say.Diamond!Congrats!

item.name: Stone Age: The Expansion
item.comment: I love the new huts. This expansion adds to the stone age feel another strategy path that fits very well to the original mechanics. However, it does not add any major differences, e.g. you don't 'make' the jewelery for points, as was my understanding from reading the description briefly. You just gather the jewelery instead of food. Jewelery is a new sub-resource that you can use to buy a card or trade for any resource, like gold. To be able to trade you have to invest in the trader, which will hurt your food production. Strategically it is a sound expansion. I however expected a complex system where you would create the jewelery out of the different materials, instead of just building huts them.

item.name: Stone Age: The New Huts
item.comment: A bit more diversity.

item.name: Strasbourg
item.comment: Not as good as other Feld games. The basic mechanic about picking as many cards in stacks as you want is solid, but the game itself does not offer something exciting.

item.name: Straw
item.comment: There seems to be no strategy in this.BUT i have played only once

item.name: Strike Dice
item.comment:
A very promising game by talented designers that looks wonderful! "-well then, why did you rate it low, you creep?"
I believe the playtesters did not do a good job at all, or this game wasn't playtested enough in a broad circle of playtesters. It would require many different playtesters, that don't hesitate to speak their opinion on a professional level. The game is very promising and full of many new mechanics (such as using the dice as pawns) but lacks certain substance that would make it more strategical.
For an abstract game it is full of theme, and only another Greek designer, Diogenis (Tony Cimino), is known for this quality (theme in abstract games).
From a graphic design point of view, the game looks absolutely amazing! only point I have to make is that it isn't clear how many spaces one has to move to get to the next "base", but this is explained clearly enough in the manual.
So, what is wrong with the gameplay? actually...quite a bit of factors hurt the gameplay. The dice roll plays a major role. Basically it seems to me that whoever rolls higher, wins. That is because simply higher rolls displace lower rolls, so there is absolutely no use for lower rolls.
How could the designers counter this? well, apparently they should find uses for the lower rolls. "Higher diplaces lower" is a very primitive mechanic. They could go with asked sets of numbers instead. They could give certain identities to each rolled number, by assigning different uses for them. There is a restriction that makes a "4" impossible to step on certain areas. There is also the rule that the "1" moves 30% more than the "4" but these are just not enough.
Both designers seem to love their job on the game and that is why I am eager to seeing more of their work in the future, however I have to ask for both of them to playtest each of their games with a large group of playtesters that they do not know personally, and listen to their opinion and constantly change the game until they get positive reviews from the playtesters.
This game could have been a hit.

item.name: Stronghold
item.comment: Innovative siege simulation game. Unlike everything I've seen. Perhaps Castle Panic resembles an extremely simplified version on the same theme. The innovative theme and game genre might attract fans. I for one look only to the gameplay. There are some interesting mechanics on this game, which provide some depth, though I have the feeling they don't reach their full potential. The game does offer replayability and manoeuvering and bluff and many other tactics.

item.name: The Struggle for Catan
item.comment: Some more buildings wouldn't hurt. It does have an ok gameplay but seems stripped down.

item.name: Struggle of Empires
item.comment: One of the truly excellent Wallace's designs, and I say this without being an area-control fan. I particularly love the many different tiles that provide truly balanced and interesting strategic choices and a lot of replayability. I would also like to see alliances to be even more committing. The dice roll to move on colonies bothers me a bit but I gotta have more plays to form an opinion about this mechanic. Another thing that bothers me is that players should consider the fact that it is costly to attack without an advantage. If they don't they could all team up randomly against a player. This is the best area control game I've played, and probably one of the best games for 6-7 players.

item.name: A Study in Emerald
item.comment: A very thematic card drafting / area influence / secret identities Wallace game. I think it plays well with all numbers of players, though the strategy is different depending on the circumstances. The cards are dripping with theme, and the mechanics seem to hold depth. It certainly feels original.

item.name: Suburbia
item.comment: An excellent economic/development game with abilities, that plays fast, has very small explanation time, has depth and balance and for once it features a very good use of the spatial tile placement element which I usually hate. I found it works very well in this game. Ted Alspach owed us a game such as this.

item.name: Such a Thing?
item.comment: Though this is made for nongamers,in my opinion it is fun only if played with clever people experienced in games.It lacks a rule clarifying if imaginary objects/persons could be accepted as answers.

item.name: Summoner Wars: Master Set
item.comment: As a light tactics game with unit effects and abilities, it's like a better neuroshima hex. But I was not as ecstatic as the rest of BGG.

item.name: Sword & Skull
item.comment: It looks like a simplified Talisman. It has a bad reputation due to the roll and move board but I tend to disagree. It provides with some options and if you need a light adventure game for a Christmas evening with non gamer friends it's right on the spot.

item.name: Sylla
item.comment: A robust bidding euro with various mechanics that offers development and interesting choices. It stands out as a complete light political game that offers all the complex aspects of a political struggle in about 1 hour and 15 min.

item.name: Taj Mahal
item.comment: One of Knizia's good games.I needed a more sophisticated/complex card-bidding mechanism to call it perfect!Terrible box cover art.I prefer it with the house rule that you score points for each connected city,instead of province

item.name: Takenoko
item.comment: An abstract family game very beautifully produced! abstract family games are the definition of exact genre I dislike. However this one was pretty straightforward and not that bad. useful as a gateway game, mainly beacause of the great artwork and theme.

item.name: Tales of the Arabian Nights
item.comment: A fully thematic interactive story game,with the most excellent components I've seen in a board game.There is a bit of strategy but a lot of options.Excellent to play with nongamers,rpgers,and gamers alike.It could be perfect if there was some more strategy to it.

item.name: Talisman (fourth edition)
item.comment: An easy going colorful fantasy adventure, in one of the best boards I've seen in a game.

item.name: Taluva
item.comment: Nice strategy,beautiful artwork on the tiles but I wish the game was richer somehow.I have also something to say about the choice of colours,they do look very nice but they are not as distinct as needed to help the gameplay.

item.name: Tammany Hall
item.comment: I hate this genre (light area control) but this game is one of the best in its category. The design is elegant and conveys much backstabbing and clever playing considering its simplicity. The rules could fit into 1 page.

item.name: TAMSK
item.comment: Abstract?yes.I don't like.Have to rush?yes.I don't like.Nice strategy?yes.I like.

item.name: Tash-Kalar: Arena of Legends
item.comment: I expected an abstract game that would amaze me from uncle Vlaada. I got an abstract game that does excel in some mechanics, but the utter chaos that rules the battlefield is a deal breaker for me. I suspect that more plays are needed to judge the game fairly, but I don't think I want to play again.

item.name: Tempus
item.comment: Hmm.this is NOT a civ game,rather an area control game.Not bad,balanced Wallace design as always,with upgraded component quality.Not as deep though as other Wallace games.I wish it was more complex though.As is,only 1 land type has a function.One thing I liked is the reason for building cities,which is not clear at the beginning.

item.name: Terra
item.comment: As good as Fauna, with a different, bit more interesting theme. What more can you ask?

item.name: Terra Evolution
item.comment: A legitimate deck building game, with the scaling-chain element prevalent. I did not like the interaction mechanics, and was not enthusiastic with the originality either.

item.name: Terra Mystica
item.comment: Another excellent development game. Resource balances and development choices are the main decisions. I would like less kingmaking to call it perfect.

item.name: Terra Nova
item.comment: An abstracted area influence. The main mechanic is not bad, but the game is too simple for more than 2-3 plays.

item.name: Texas Zombies
item.comment: A reimplementation of Cat and chocolate but with a hilarious theme. Could be funnier.

item.name: Thebes
item.comment: Very good turn order mechanism(one of the best I've seen). A thematic euro introductory game of choice, that doesn't get old after many plays. Wish it lasted 5% more.

item.name: The Thief of Baghdad
item.comment: No.Too many back and forth moves.There is some balance, but it does not save face.

item.name: Through the Ages: A New Story of Civilization
item.comment: Best non-transferable to older edition changes are the leaders and wonders tweaks. Other rules changes could be easily trasnferred to older editions. I dislike the colourful artwork, preferred the older one. Still a 10.

item.name: Through the Ages: A Story of Civilization
item.comment: Best game I've played by far.Lasts enough,technologies,wonders,leaders,lots of strategy to discover,extremely well designed gameplay(bravo to the playtesters also!),diverse cards,different ways to victory,beautiful development.Very addictive!Sets the bar very high!There won't be another game like this for a long time.Mr Chvatil,expansion please!

item.name: Thunderstone
item.comment: Clearly better than Dominion.Best reason,the Vp's here are monsters with abilities.You can level up your characters.And the theme is incorporated into the mechanics of the game.Not so many impressive combos as Dominion though.And it could be a lot better even with simple variant rules.

item.name: Thunderstone Advance: Towers of Ruin
item.comment: It's just a bit better than thunderstone. Changes are nothing too great I think.

item.name: Thunderstone: Dragonspire
item.comment: The best expansion there is, boosts component quality and content.

item.name: Thurn and Taxis
item.comment: Nice family / network building game,extremely well balanced,Menzel artwork.Probably the medium family of choice.

item.name: Tichu
item.comment: A nicer trick taking game with a twist. It's main mechanic doesn't differ much from other trick taking games, however small details do make a difference in this one. Recommended with 4 players.

item.name: Ticket to Ride: MÃ¤rklin
item.comment: A somewhat nice family network building game. I like the scoring mechanisms. I prefer thurn and taxis.

item.name: Tide of Iron
item.comment: An excellent in gameplay and production quality, medium-heavy (rather medium I'd say) complexity squad conflict wargame. Extremely fond of the choice between suppressive and lethal attacks, combining forces in one attack or splitting the offensive in many actions. Command points and card actions make the game shine even more.

item.name: Tigris & Euphrates
item.comment: Yea,it's as good as chess,but I hate chess

item.name: Tikal
item.comment: Probably the reference exploration euro. The theme is actually incorporated pretty good imo and the board during play is beautiful. An interesting addition would be if treasures had also special effects instead of just the set collection mechanic.

item.name: Timbuktu
item.comment: I'm afraid I was harsh in my rating, but that reflects the fact that I was frustrated during the whole course of the game. During the 2nd round things were a bit better. It seems like a promising idea that remained abstract and just doesn't work as well as planned. You can play the game, it's not bad or broken, but I for one did not enjoy it. So far the only Dirk Henn game I very much enjoyed is Shogun.

item.name: Timeline: Discoveries
item.comment: Excellent! party game of choice :) simple idea that works well. I wish for a more strategic game though, with more choices, e.g. special cards that let you draft out certain discoveries, or give you 2 placement chances, e.t.c.

item.name: Timeline: Inventions
item.comment: A clever and simple family game with very nice illustrations/artwork. I wished for a tiny bit more rules though, to boost replayability.

item.name: Tinners' Trail
item.comment: A classic Wallace game. It's fun with all the nice Wallace balances and it tilts (*just a bit*) to the "family game" side, with its small duration. Personally I'd prefer a longer game, with more development, but it is also nice in its own version. Not at all disappointed! checks through by me!

item.name: Tiny Epic Defenders
item.comment: Indeed it is a nice simple cooperative game which conveys strongly the sense of defense. Mechanics are simpler than what I would prefer, but still a solid game.

item.name: Tiny Epic Galaxies
item.comment: I was not enthusiastic. Just an ok compact game.

item.name: Tiny Epic Galaxies: Satellites & Super Weapons Mini Expansion
item.comment: Nothing special I'm afraid.

item.name: To Court the King
item.comment:
Very good dice management game from Tom Lehman, years before Troyes. It has a bit more interaction than roll through the ages, which it resembles dice-wise, since the players also compete directly to eachother for buying the cards before they run out. Very nice indeed!
After some plays, I can see some depth!

item.name: Tobago
item.comment: Great introductory game that offers hidden strategies so it isn't boring even for heavy gamers. It could be even better if each treasure type differed from the rest.

item.name: Toledo
item.comment: The caylus-resembling mechanism with multiple pawns advancing through the buildings works well. The duels are simplistic. I wanted more imagination on the player choices, but I do enjoy the game.

item.name: Tomb
item.comment: A very nicely illustrated dungeon crawl with interesting and balanced mechanics. I would rate extremely high if the combat system was a bit more elaborate. The map configuration also could be better with if it contained an exploration element. A good game overall.

item.name: Torres
item.comment: This is an abstract game I would play again.And I hate abstract games.

item.name: Tournay
item.comment: Seems like a promising idea for a gameplay, but these kind of games depend solely on the cleverness of the cards' abilities. So, I need to play again to judge the depth.

item.name: Town Center
item.comment: A design that perfectly draws the line between abstract and thematic game. It is also a nice game to play, although I'd expect a little bit more from the drafting mechanic.

item.name: Traders of Osaka
item.comment: A simple reference commerce game, not bad.

item.name: Tragedy Looper
item.comment: Excellent idea, poor application. Graphic design doesn't help. Component mechanics neither. Fans of deduction games will like it. I am eager to see the same idea in a more streamlined version.

item.name: Trains
item.comment: A dominion clone with a map and a train theme. Works well. The innovative elements are the Waste cards you have to take with each action on the map and the fact that the map actions limit your deck building capabilities and offer dual focus strategies. They both work well, but it does not take deck building one step further, like ascension does.

item.name: Trains: Rising Sun
item.comment: A dominion clone with a map and a train theme. Works well. The innovative elements are the Waste cards you have to take with each action on the map and the fact that the map actions limit your deck building capabilities and offer dual focus strategies. They both work well, but it does not take deck building one step further, like ascension does. I do not prefer the attack cards.

item.name: Trajan
item.comment: A collection of mini games very well tied together. An abstract mechanic defines the balance between your actions. There are many ways to score and there are some ways to produce more actions, a bit like Burgen. It is a good game, I was fascinated at first but then I wished for a more immediate way of choosing my actions rather than the abstract rondel. The game's strategy is mainly choosing which action benefits you most at the time, but there are also some long term benefits that you can tie in to your style of play. I was only frustrated by the rondel and just a bit. The game itself is great.

item.name: Trans Europa
item.comment: A light network building (euphemism) game. Nothing special at all.

item.name: Travel Blog
item.comment: Another nice party game from Vlaada. Fast, fun and simple. Not sure about replayability.

item.name: Treasure Chest
item.comment: Adds many good wanted expansions, particularly for puerto rico, san juan, notre dame and im jahr des drachen. I own only the Notre dame expansion as this game is in my top 10 list!

item.name: Tribune: Primus Inter Pares
item.comment: Could have been a good game if it had better distinguishable components.There are a lot of choices but also the feeling that something is missing.

item.name: Trivial Pursuit
item.comment: ARGH!

item.name: Troyes
item.comment: An excellent worker placement/action management game that is nothing like kingsburg. I don't have a clue why people compare the two. The strategies and gameplay differ completely. There are some ways to reroll or alter your dice, and there are actions that use the number rolled and others that use the number of dice available. A very good game overall, and also the expansion is great.

item.name: Troyes: Bonus Cards
item.comment: Nothing too essential.

item.name: TSCHAK!
item.comment: A very beautifully illustrated fantasy themed trick taking game, which is simple enough to be a great filler.

item.name: Tsuro
item.comment: It's like metro,only better.

item.name: Tumblin-Dice
item.comment: I like it. It should be sold with dice for at least 6 people though. I would prefer some more rules, heavier dice, perhaps a different surface as well (e.g. velvet in some parts). Still it is fun enough as it is!

item.name: Tumblin-Dice Medium
item.comment: Although playable and still fun, I would definitely go for the large edition.

item.name: Turbo Taxi
item.comment: An extra light puzzle game. Nice mechanic, but too plain for my taste, feels like an uncomplete game.

item.name: Turn the Tide
item.comment: Original for its time.

item.name: Twilight Imperium (Third Edition)
item.comment: Very nice thematically,it reminds me of the computer game Masters of Orion II.The graphic design of this game is its basic flaw.I needed more illustrations but mainly I needed rule remiders.Particularly the technologies needed some illustrations and should be better depicted in a player aid,and their possible effects on each player mat.Some of the laws are devastating.I expected mainly a space civ development game.However it does make a very thematic space battles game.And the different units are perfectly minimal designed to be intuitive and less confusing than other similar games.

item.name: Twilight Struggle
item.comment: I am not a fan of territory influence games.This however is one of the most thematic territory control games there are.Its mechanism defines what territory control games should be like.I did not find the gameplay actually perfect.It is hard to remember all these card effects,so probably the game becomes more enjoyable after many plays.I do not like the fact that all these cards' only way of interacting with the game is to change an influence number on the board.

item.name: Two Rooms and a Bang!
item.comment: Handles well a large number of players. Other than that, I needed a tad more structure in the rules and less in the role abilities.

item.name: Two Rooms and a Boom
item.comment: Well it is one of few games that feature so many players, so we have to give it some credit for it. Other than that, I think it could be even better.

item.name: Tzolk'in: The Mayan Calendar
item.comment: A great euro that does not stop at just one great innovation. Seems deep enough and there are many strategies to explore. Need more plays!

item.name: Tzolk'in: The Mayan Calendar â€“ Tribes & Prophecies
item.comment: Player starting abilities and new buildings are two great features! I didn't like the calamities much. The promo ability is unbalanced - needs FAQ.

item.name: Tzolk'in: The Mayan Calendar â€“ Tribes & Prophecies â€“ Mini Expansion 1
item.comment: Rules clarification needed - major exploit with the calamities that ask for resources!

item.name: Uchronia
item.comment: Glory to rome v2.0 with many common mechanics. Most prominent change is that there is a dedicated buildings offer. This is a game where the number of players plays a major role I think. I would definetely not recommend the game with 2 players, 4 would be the sweetspot, 5 would create much downtime.

item.name: Ugg-Tect
item.comment: Although it seemed a great idea, I think it doesn't deliver 100% of the fun it is supposed to.

item.name: Union Pacific
item.comment: A good light train-stockholding game that manifests almost all 18XX basic strategies: shares, blocking, bluff. It does not have the economic element. It can be used either as a normal euro game, or as an introductory game to 18XX. Mind you, the game has robust strategies and takes about 1.5 hours to play, but can be explained in under 2 minutes. Another nice but different game in this category is Wallace's Steel Driver which I also enjoyed.

item.name: Urban Sprawl
item.comment: It's a perfectly nice area influence economic city building game, although I would be more grateful if there was some artwork on the cards and if the character (dictated by the different events) of each of the four building types was apparent somehow on the board. I prefer it from Dominant Species.

item.name: Urbania
item.comment: A fully thematic game with hilarious box art cover made by the designer himself.Theme Category Winner of the greekguild's boardgamedesign contest 2009.The freedom that riots represent is somewhat claustrophobic in this tight area game,giving it a darker feel than expected.Need more plays to evaluate the gameplay,I only had time for a glance at the game.

item.name: Uruk II: Die Entwicklung Geht Weiter
item.comment: Not too different from Uruk, better illustrations and components though. A very nice compact game. I dislike the fact that they made a larger box - old Uruk could fit in a large pocket.

item.name: Uruk: Wiege der Zivilisation
item.comment: Excellent!simple rules and substantial depth.It is also fun!I put it next to Glory To Rome.I would rate 10 if there were 5 more discoveries.A must for every collection.

item.name: Valley of the Kings
item.comment: A nice fast deck building compact game.

item.name: Valley of the Mammoths
item.comment: Faidutti's professionalism shines 20 years ago,by creating a fun game of sweetspot complexity with magnificient cartoon sketches and fulfilling gameplay.Better than Evo.My only concern is that it should have a second victory condition in case it takes too long.Perhaps multiple attempts of instantly owning 4+ tents.

item.name: Vanuatu
item.comment: The game is fierce! it seems like an innocent euro but too often one faces the choice of destroying another player's full round. By analyzing the meta game, one could conclude that it is rather more profitable to counter whatever hostile actions you can rather than try to simply use your workers for beneficial actions. I do not think the common taste is fit for this kind of vicious interaction.

item.name: Vasco da Gama
item.comment: An excellent euro with beautiful components and artwork. Exceptionally innovative action order mechanic. I'd like to see such a civ game. I'd also prefer it just a slightly bit heavier.

item.name: Vault Wars
item.comment: A nice surprise, I liked the notion of bidding for unknown vaut contents. Resembles History Channel's "Storage Wars" show.

item.name: Vault Wars: Worker Expansion
item.comment: I think this module can be easily omitted as it slows down the game and makes it fiddlier and more euro-like, which doesn't help it.

item.name: Il Vecchio
item.comment: This is a good euro. The only thing I did not like was the only original mechanic :D - the rotating mediators. But it's not that bad. Other than that, I'd like one more ability per player in the game setup and in the game end to call it even better. Not a waste of time.

item.name: VerrÃ¤ter
item.comment: Not as good as meuterer. Similar good artwork, some common mechanics.

item.name: Village
item.comment: A nice euro with an innovation and beautiful components. I would call this a game of mid-term strategies. There are a few of them to pursue, but I was not enthusiastic about the overall depth. If you like euro games, this is another nice one.

item.name: Vinhos
item.comment: Seems like a robust economic game, but a bit dry. Have to try again.

item.name: Viticulture
item.comment: A very well produced and streamlined worker placement game. For me it is the preferred out of the 3 with the same theme (vinhos,grand cru).I would also like to see a non-linear wine maturity. Other than that, game is great although I would recommend it with up to 4 players unless you don't mind the duration.

item.name: Viticulture: Kickstarter Promotional Cards
item.comment: Nothing too essential, but adds some nice variety.

item.name: VivaJava: The Coffee Game
item.comment: A negotiation/bluff race that works well, with a nice theme and nice components. I did not feel very much the cultivating component of the coffee production process.

item.name: The Voyages of Marco Polo
item.comment: An innovative design that provides a game hard to master, with ecxeptional rule-bending characters that provide a totally different experience with each game. A great game!

item.name: De Vulgari Eloquentia
item.comment: A very controversial game! I have many things to say but I'll just skip to the conlusion: this had the potential to be a great and euro with a very innovative theme, however it feels to be still in playtest beta version. I love the artwork and some mechanics, but many of them are obviously excessive and needed fine tuning. I expect more playtesting from Mr Papini's next game, which I am looking forward to.

item.name: Waagemut
item.comment: Adds a bit more strategy to the base game.

item.name: Warhammer 40,000: Conquest
item.comment: Not what I was looking for. Warhammer invasion way better. This feels like Call of Cthulhu LCG.

item.name: Warhammer: Invasion
item.comment: Î•xcellent! A bit of resource management and a gameplay that reaches magic the gathering.I do miss the different lands however and I don't really enjoy -actually I dislike- warhammer theme. The graphic design is perhaps overly flamboyant and heavy.

item.name: Warhammer: Invasion â€“ Assault on Ulthuan
item.comment: This, unfortunately is a must have, as it introduces the elves.

item.name: Warhammer: Invasion â€“ The Deathmaster's Dance
Warhammer: Invasion â€“ Tooth and Claw
Warrior Knights
item.comment: This is a nice game,although clearly inferior -and a lot similar- to runewars.I wish for a bigger map,less battles,and more development.Should someone pay more to buy runewars?well I'd pay 20 euro more,but no more.

item.name: Wars of the Roses: Lancaster vs. York
item.comment: A very nice simultaneous unit deployment area control game. The theme and the map remind me of the vintage computer game, "Defender of the crown"

item.name: Washington's War
item.comment:
The best wargame I've played. It reminds me of Hannibal. In a good way. I also like the theme: people rise all over the country against the self-appointed royalty who thinks world is its colony. I hope this is a lesson to modern day superpowers!
I like the colony control element and the different drm's in battle. I like the artwork. Perhaps GMT's best board in a game. I even enjoyed the historical accuracy though I almost never pay any attention to it in other games. I like the mechanics. I don't care that they are so like Hannibal. I like Hannibal. I like Washington's War.
Recommended to every wargamer.

item.name: Watson & Holmes: From the Diaries of 221B
item.comment: Well, it is like a more gamified Sherlock Holmes Consulting Detective. Nothing too fancy on the mechanics, it just makes the game more competitive and strategic. It is as good as its stories. The first one was not disappointing!

item.name: Wazabi
item.comment: For its genre (pointless back and forth interaction with minimum strategy) it's one of the best I've played.

item.name: Welcome to the Dungeon
item.comment: An excellent, ultra quick and light push your luck.

item.name: The Werewolves of Miller's Hollow
item.comment: We always play it with custom characters and a werewolf leader with special abilities.There is not one friend of mine that I haven't persuaded to play this game.

item.name: WeyKick
item.comment: A nice foosball, truly innovative way of controlling the players through the magnet, however I felt it could be even better somehow.

item.name: Who is Who
item.comment: A somewhat fun party game. We play this version: we stick id's in our foreheads and keep asking YES/NO questions until we get a NO. then it's the next player's turn.

item.name: Who Would Win
item.comment: Ultra light role playing fun game. Depends on the game group completely. I can't stop thinking that with some extra limitations/rules/guides it could be even better.

item.name: Wir sind das Volk!
item.comment: A lighter twilight struggle (with unrelated mechanics but same feeling nevertheless) in the theme of 1989. The game plays well and has interesting balances and variable ways to victory to be explored.

item.name: The Witcher Adventure Game
item.comment: There are some fresh mechanics at work here, but I fear the depth of this game is not what I expected after having tried lots of runebound-clones. It makes a great adventure family game though.

item.name: Wits & Wagers
item.comment: Great party game!the first trivia game I like after Fauna.Although it has a lot of localized questions.

item.name: Wiz-War (eighth edition)
item.comment: Dungeon Twister killer. I wished for some more control over what and how many cards come in my hand. Other than that, a simple, colourful, with many spells to choose from and explore their combo uses. Feels like a less abstract dungeon twister, wished for a longer playtime.

item.name: Wizard
item.comment: A landmark trick taking game. The prediction element makes it shine. Many variations with a simple deck of cards exist. In Greece it is only played by respected elders in traditional village-style coffee places and it is called "prefa".

item.name: Wool Rules
item.comment: Nice simple press your luck bidding filler. Not too much depth. Could be better but still.

item.name: World of Warcraft: The Adventure Game
item.comment: Nothing too disappointing, nothing too special either...a reference adventure game.Nice board and card quality.

item.name: World of Warcraft: The Boardgame
item.comment: I like the innovative combat mechanic that resembles distantly that of runebound. It provides aspects for interaction with the creature and item abilities. I dislike the mechanic of the neutral creatures. It also could feature more elaborate winning conditions. Excellent in content, a must if you like character development games.

item.name: World Without End
item.comment: Very nice and diverse.With an event at your every tiny move,it gives you the idea of slow motion.However,it feels that it is so balanced that there is no winning strategy.Not at all a copy of Pillars.Magnificient board,all-shiny Menzel.

item.name: Yedo
item.comment: A worker placement/set collection, much like lords of waterdeep. You are trying to complete missions that have certain requirements, only here you do not 'pay' the needed components, thus one could maintain a specific strategy throughout the game.

item.name: Yggdrasil
item.comment: A balanced coop game with good difficulty and simple mechanics.

item.name: Yggdrasil: Frigg Promo
item.comment: It's an ok ability, nothing special, could be used wisely.

item.name: Yggdrasil: Vidar Promo
item.comment: Not one of my favorites.

item.name: You're Bluffing!
item.comment: Exceptionally original through simple mechanics. A bidding game that stands out in its simplicity -if you don't mind some serious bluffing fails!

item.name: Ys
item.comment: An ok bidding euro with interconnecting choices.I am not so sure though if all these connections help the gameplay quality.

item.name: Yspahan
item.comment: A great simple euro with nice components. Resembles pickomino considering the dice group mechanism. Lots of hidden strategies inside this little diamond!

item.name: Yspahan: The Souks
item.comment: A nice but not essential variant deck.

item.name: Ystari Box
item.comment: Useful expansions. Some are almost a must. Not silly at all.

item.name: Yunnan
item.comment: Seems a good development/build up euro in the footsteps of e.g. Hansa Teutonica, although I disliked that it forces you to closely monitor other player's future actions as they can be devastating to your planning.

item.name: ZhanGuo
item.comment: It is a good euro but I was unable to grasp some aspects of the strategy, and was left with the feeling of unnecessary complexity.

item.name: Ziegen Kriegen
item.comment: Liked the artwork. Didn't get the strategy that much.

item.name: Zombie Dice
item.comment: Fast and extra simple push your luck. Wish for some more rules/strategy. I heard the deluxe edition comes with real human brains.

item.name: ÎœÎ±Î³Î³ÎµÎ»Î¬Î½Î¿Ï‚
item.comment: A bidding family game, that becomes very familiar (in a good sense) after the first play.
